verses.textLa: Angelus autem Domini locutus est ad Philippum, dicens: Surge, et vade contra meridianum ad viam, quæ descendit ab Ierusalem in Gazam: hæc est deserta.

verses.textEn: And rising up, he went. And behold, an Ethiopian man, a eunuch, powerful under Candace, the queen of the Ethiopians, who was over all her treasures, had arrived in Jerusalem to worship.
verses.textLa: Et surgens abiit. Et ecce vir Æthiops, eunuchus, potens Candacis Reginæ Æthiopum, qui erat super omnes gazas eius: venerat adorare in Ierusalem:

verses.textEn: And while returning, he was sitting upon his chariot and reading from the prophet Isaiah.
verses.textLa: et revertebatur sedens super currum suum, legensque Isaiam prophetam.

verses.textEn: Then the Spirit said to Philip, “Draw near and join yourself to this chariot.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Spiritus Philippo: Accede, et adiunge te ad currum istum.

verses.textEn: And Philip, hurrying, heard him reading from the prophet Isaiah, and he said, “Do you think that you understand what you are reading?”
verses.textLa: Accurrens autem Philippus, audivit eum legentem Isaiam prophetam, et dixit: Putasne intelligis quæ legis?

verses.textEn: And he said, “But how can I, unless someone will have revealed it to me?” And he asked Philip to climb up and sit with him.
verses.textLa: Qui ait: Et quomodo possum, si non aliquis ostenderit mihi? Rogavitque Philippum ut ascenderet, et sederet secum.

verses.textEn: Now the place in Scripture that he was reading was this: “Like a sheep he was led to the slaughter. And like a lamb silent before his shearer, so he opened not his mouth.
verses.textLa: Locus autem Scripturæ, quem legebat, erat hic: Tamquam ovis ad occisionem ductus est: et sicus agnus coram tondente se, sine voce, sic non aperuit os suum.

verses.textEn: He endured his judgment with humility. Who of his generation shall describe how his life was taken away from the earth?”
verses.textLa: In humilitate iudicium eius sublatum est. Generationem eius quis enarrabit, quoniam tolletur de terra vita eius?

verses.textEn: Then the eunuch responded to Philip, saying: “I beg you, about whom is the prophet saying this? About himself, or about someone else?”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem eunuchus Philippo, dixit: Obsecro te, de quo Propheta dicit hoc? de se, an de alio aliquo?

verses.textEn: Then Philip, opening his mouth and beginning from this Scripture, evangelized Jesus to him.
verses.textLa: Aperiens autem Philippus os suum, et incipiens a Scriptura ista, evangelizavit illi Iesum.

verses.textEn: And while they were going along the way, they arrived at a certain water source. And the eunuch said: “There is water. What would prevent me from being baptized?”
verses.textLa: Et dum irent per viam, venerunt ad quamdam aquam: et ait Eunuchus: Ecce aqua, quid prohibet me baptizari?

verses.textEn: Then Philip said, “If you believe from your whole heart, it is permitted.” And he responded by saying, “I believe the Son of God to be Jesus the Christ.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Philippus: Si credis ex toto corde, licet. Et respondens ait: Credo, Filium Dei esse Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: And he ordered the chariot to stand still. And both Philip and the eunuch descended into the water. And he baptized him.
verses.textLa: Et iussit stare currum: et descenderunt uterque in aquam, Philippus et Eunuchus, et baptizavit eum.

verses.textEn: And when they had ascended from the water, the Spirit of the Lord took Philip away, and the eunuch did not see him anymore. Then he went on his way, rejoicing.
verses.textLa: Cum autem ascendissent de aqua, Spiritus Domini rapuit Philippum, et amplius non vidit eum Eunuchus. Ibat autem per viam suam gaudens.

verses.textEn: Now Philip was found in Azotus. And continuing on, he evangelized all the cities, until he arrived in Caesarea.
verses.textLa: Philippus autem inventus est in Azoto, et pertransiens evangelizabat civitatibus cunctis, donec veniret Cæsaream.

verses.textEn: Now Saul, still breathing threats and beatings against the disciples of the Lord, went to the high priest,
verses.textLa: Saulus autem adhuc spirans minarum, et cædis in discipulos Domini, accessit ad principem sacerdotum,

verses.textEn: and he petitioned him for letters to the synagogues in Damascus, so that, if he found any men or women belonging to this Way, he could lead them as prisoners to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: et petiit ab eo epistolas in Damascum ad synagogas: ut si quos invenisset huius Viæ viros, ac mulieres, vinctos perduceret in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And as he made the journey, it happened that he was approaching Damascus. And suddenly, a light from heaven shone around him.
verses.textLa: Et cum iter faceret, contigit ut appropinquaret Damasco: et subito circumfulsit eum lux de cælo.

verses.textEn: And falling to the ground, he heard a voice saying to him, “Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?”
verses.textLa: Et cadens in terram audivit vocem dicentem sibi: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris?

verses.textEn: And he said, “Who are you, Lord?” And he: “I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting. It is hard for you to kick against the goad.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixit: Quis es Domine? Et ille: Ego sum Iesus, quem tu persequeris. Durum est tibi contra stimulum calcitrare.
verses.notes: The text literally says ‘kick against the goad,’ but this is an idiomatic expression meaning: ‘It is hard for you to resist the will of God,’ in other words: it is hard to act against Divine Providence and grace. This phrase occurs twice in Acts and in this translation is given in two different wordings, each of which reveals the meaning of the idiomatic expression, rather than translating that expression literally and obscurely.

verses.textEn: And he, trembling and astonished, said, “Lord, what do you want me to do?”
verses.textLa: Et tremens, ac stupens dixit: Domine, quid me vis facere?

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him, “Rise up and go into the city, and there you will be told what you ought to do.” Now the men who were accompanying him were standing stupefied, hearing indeed a voice, but seeing no one.
verses.textLa: Et Dominus ad eum: Surge, et ingredere civitatem, et ibi dicetur tibi quid te oporteat facere. Viri autem illi, qui comitabantur cum eo, stabant stupefacti, audientes quidem vocem, neminem autem videntes.

verses.textEn: Then Saul rose up from the ground. And upon opening his eyes, he saw nothing. So leading him by the hand, they brought him into Damascus.
verses.textLa: Surrexit autem Saulus de terra, apertisque oculis nihil videbat. Ad manus autem illum trahentes, introduxerunt Damascum.

verses.textEn: And in that place, he was without sight for three days, and he neither ate nor drank.
verses.textLa: Et erat ibi tribus diebus non videns, et non manducavit, neque bibit.

verses.textEn: Now there was a certain disciple at Damascus, named Ananias. And the Lord said to him in a vision, “Ananias!” And he said, “Here I am, Lord.”
verses.textLa: Erat autem quidam discipulus Damasci, nomine Ananias: et dixit ad illum in visu Dominus: Anania. At ille ait: Ecce ego, Domine.

verses.textEn: And the Lord said to him: “Rise up and go into the street that is called Straight, and seek, in the house of Judas, the one named Saul of Tarsus. For behold, he is praying.”
verses.textLa: Et Dominus ad eum: Surge, et vade in vicum, qui vocatur rectus: et quære in domo Iudæ Saulum nomine Tarsensem: ecce enim orat.

verses.textEn: (And Paul saw a man named Ananias entering and imposing hands upon him, so that he might receive his sight.)
verses.textLa: (Et vidit virum Ananiam nomine, introeuntem, et imponentem sibi manus ut visum recipiat.)

verses.textEn: But Ananias responded: “Lord, I have heard from many about this man, how much harm he has done to your saints in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Respondit autem Ananias: Domine, audivi a multis de viro hoc, quanta mala fecerit sanctis tuis in Ierusalem:

verses.textEn: And he has authority here from the leaders of the priests to bind all who invoke your name.”
verses.textLa: et hic habet potestatem a principibus sacerdotum alligandi omnes, qui invocant nomen tuum.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to him: “Go, for this one is an instrument chosen by me to convey my name before nations and kings and the sons of Israel.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem ad eum Dominus: Vade, quoniam vas electionis est mihi iste, ut portet nomen meum coram Gentibus, et regibus, et filiis Israel.

verses.textEn: For I will reveal to him how much he must suffer on behalf of my name.”
verses.textLa: Ego enim ostendam illi quanta oporteat eum pro nomine meo pati.

verses.textEn: And Ananias departed. And he entered the house. And laying his hands upon him, he said: “Brother Saul, the Lord Jesus, he who appeared to you on the way by which you arrived, sent me so that you would receive your sight and be filled with the Holy Spirit.”
verses.textLa: Et abiit Ananias, et introivit in domum: et imponens ei manus, dixit: Saule frater, Dominus misit me Iesus, qui apparuit tibi in via, qua veniebas ut videas, et implearis Spiritu Sancto.

verses.textEn: And immediately, it was as if scales had fallen from his eyes, and he received his sight. And rising up, he was baptized.
verses.textLa: Et confestim ceciderunt ab oculis eius tamquam squamæ, et visum recepit: et surgens baptizatus est.

verses.textEn: And when he had taken a meal, he was strengthened. Now he was with the disciples who were at Damascus for some days.
verses.textLa: Et cum accepisset cibum, confortatus est. Fuit autem cum discipulis, qui erant Damasci, per dies aliquot.

verses.textEn: And he was continuously preaching Jesus in the synagogues: that he is the Son of God.
verses.textLa: Et continuo in synagogis prædicabat Iesum, quoniam hic est Filius Dei.

verses.textEn: And all who heard him were astonished, and they said, “Is this not the one who, in Jerusalem, was fighting against those invoking this name, and who came here for this: so that he might lead them away to the leaders of the priests?”
verses.textLa: Stupebant autem omnes, qui audiebant, et dicebant: Nonne hic est, qui expugnabat in Ierusalem eos, qui invocabant nomen istud: et huc ad hoc venit ut vinctos illos duceret ad principes sacerdotum?

verses.textEn: But Saul was increasing to a greater extent in ability, and so he was confounding the Jews who lived at Damascus, by affirming that he is the Christ.
verses.textLa: Saulus autem multo magis convalescebat, et confundebat Iudæos, qui habitabant Damasci, affirmans quoniam hic est Christus.

verses.textEn: And when many days were completed, the Jews took counsel as one, so that they might put him to death.
verses.textLa: Cum autem implerentur dies multi, consilium fecerunt in unum Iudæi ut eum interficerent.

verses.textEn: But their treachery became known to Saul. Now they were also watching the gates, day and night, so that they might put him to death.
verses.textLa: Notæ autem factæ sunt Saulo insidiæ eorum. Custodiebant autem et portas die ac nocte, ut eum interficerent.

verses.textEn: But the disciples, taking him away by night, sent him over the wall by letting him down in a basket.
verses.textLa: Accipientes autem eum discipuli nocte, per murum dimiserunt eum, submittentes in sporta.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived in Jerusalem, he attempted to join himself to the disciples. And they were all afraid of him, not believing that he was a disciple.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venisset in Ierusalem, tentabat se iungere discipulis, et omnes timebant eum, non credentes quod esset discipulus.

verses.textEn: But Barnabas took him aside and led him to the Apostles. And he explained to them how he had seen the Lord, and that he had spoken to him, and how, in Damascus, he had acted faithfully in the name of Jesus.
verses.textLa: Barnabas autem apprehensum illum duxit ad Apostolos: et narravit illis quomodo in via vidisset Dominum, et quia locutus est ei, et quomodo in Damasco fiducialiter egerit in nomine Iesu.

verses.textEn: And he was with them, entering and departing Jerusalem, and acting faithfully in the name of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et erat cum illis intrans, et exiens in Ierusalem, et fiducialiter agens in nomine Domini.

verses.textEn: He also was speaking with the Gentiles and disputing with the Greeks. But they were seeking to kill him.
verses.textLa: Loquebatur quoque Gentibus, et disputabat cum Græcis: illi autem quærebant occidere eum.

verses.textEn: And when the brothers had realized this, they brought him to Caesarea and sent him away to Tarsus.
verses.textLa: Quod cum cognovissent fratres, deduxerunt eum Cæsaream, et dimiserunt Tarsum.

verses.textEn: Certainly, the Church had peace throughout all of Judea and Galilee and Samaria, and it was being built up, while walking in the fear of the Lord, and it was being filled with the consolation of the Holy Spirit.
verses.textLa: Ecclesia quidem per totam Iudæam, et Galilæam, et Samariam habebat pacem, et ædificabatur ambulans in timore Domini, et consolatione Sancti Spiritus replebatur.

verses.textEn: Then it happened that Peter, as he traveled around everywhere, came to the saints who were living at Lydda.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, ut Petrus dum pertransiret universos, deveniret ad sanctos, qui habitabant Lyddæ.

verses.textEn: But he found there a certain man, named Aeneas, who was a paralytic, who had lain in bed for eight years.
verses.textLa: Invenit autem ibi hominem quendam, nomine Æneam, ab annis octo iacentem in grabato, qui erat paralyticus.

verses.textEn: And Peter said to him: “Aeneas, the Lord Jesus Christ heals you. Rise up and arrange your bed.” And immediately he rose up.
verses.textLa: Et ait illi Petrus: Ænea, sanat te Dominus Iesus Christus: surge, et sterne tibi. Et continuo surrexit.

verses.textEn: And all who were living in Lydda and Sharon saw him, and they were converted to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et viderunt eum omnes, qui habitabant Lyddæ, et Saronæ: qui conversi sunt ad Dominum.

verses.textEn: Now in Joppa there was a certain disciple named Tabitha, which in translation is called Dorcas. She was filled with the good works and almsgiving that she was accomplishing.
verses.textLa: In Ioppe autem fuit quædam discipula, nomine Tabitha, quæ interpretata dicitur Dorcas. Hæc erat plena operibus bonis, et eleemosynis, quas faciebat.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, in those days, she became ill and died. And when they had washed her, they laid her in an upper room.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem in diebus illis, ut infirmata moreretur. Quam cum lavissent, posuerunt eam in cœnaculo.

verses.textEn: Now since Lydda was close to Joppa, the disciples, upon hearing that Peter was there, sent two men to him, asking him: “Do not be slow in coming to us.”
verses.textLa: Cum autem prope esset Lydda ad Ioppen, discipuli audientes quia Petrus esset in ea, miserunt duos viros ad eum, rogantes: Ne pigriteris venire ad nos.

verses.textEn: Then Peter, rising up, went with them. And when he had arrived, they led him to an upper room. And all the widows were standing around him, weeping and showing him the tunics and garments that Dorcas had made for them.
verses.textLa: Exurgens autem Petrus venit cum illis. Et cum advenisset, duxerunt illum in cœnaculum: et circumsteterunt illum omnes viduæ flentes, et ostendentes ei tunicas, et vestes, quas faciebat illis Dorcas.

verses.textEn: And when they had all been sent outside, Peter, kneeling down, prayed. And turning to the body, he said: “Tabitha, arise.” And she opened her eyes and, upon seeing Peter, sat up again.
verses.textLa: Eiectis autem omnibus foras: Petrus ponens genua oravit: et conversus ad corpus, dixit: Tabitha, surge. At illa aperuit oculos suos: et viso Petro, resedit.

verses.textEn: And offering her his hand, he lifted her up. And when he had called in the saints and the widows, he presented her alive.
verses.textLa: Dans autem illi manum, erexit eam. Et cum vocasset sanctos, et viduas, assignavit eam vivam.

verses.textEn: Now this became known throughout all of Joppa. And many believed in the Lord.
verses.textLa: Notum autem factum est per universam Ioppen: et crediderunt multi in Domino.

verses.textEn: And it happened that he resided for many days in Joppa, with a certain Simon, a tanner.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem ut dies multos moraretur in Ioppe, apud Simonem quendam coriarium.

verses.textEn: Now there was a certain man in Caesarea, named Cornelius, a centurion of the cohort which is called Italian,
verses.textLa: Vir autem quidam erat in Cæsarea, nomine Cornleius, Centurio cohortis, quæ dicitur Italica,

verses.textEn: a devout man, fearing God with all his house, giving many alms to the people, and praying to God continually.
verses.textLa: religiosus, ac timens Deum cum omni domo sua, faciens eleemosynas multas plebi, et deprecans Deum semper:

verses.textEn: This man saw in a vision clearly, at about the ninth hour of the day, the Angel of God entering to him and saying to him: “Cornelius!”
verses.textLa: is vidit in visu manifeste, quasi hora diei nona, Angelum Dei introeuntem ad se, et dicentem sibi: Corneli.

verses.textEn: And he, gazing at him, was seized by fear, and he said, “What is it, lord?” And he said to him: “Your prayers and your almsgiving have ascended as a memorial in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: At ille intuens eum, timore correptus, dixit: Quid est, domine? Dixit autem illi: Orationes tuæ, et eleemosynæ tuæ ascenderunt in memoriam in conspectu Dei.

verses.textEn: And now, send men to Joppa and summon a certain Simon, who is surnamed Peter.
verses.textLa: Et nunc mitte viros in Ioppen, et accersi Simonem quendam, qui cognominatur Petrus:

verses.textEn: This man is a guest with a certain Simon, a tanner, whose house is beside the sea. He will tell you what you must do.”
verses.textLa: hic hospitatur apud Simonem quendam coriarium, cuius est domus iuxta mare: hic dicet tibi quid te oporteat facere.

verses.textEn: And when the Angel who was speaking to him had departed, he called, out of those who were subject to him, two of his household servants and a soldier who feared the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et cum discessisset Angelus qui loquebatur illi, vocavit duos domesticos suos, et militem metuentem Dominum ex his, qui illi parebant.

verses.textEn: And when he had explained everything to them, he sent them to Joppa.
verses.textLa: Quibus cum narrasset omnia, misit illos in Ioppen.

verses.textEn: Then, on the following day, while they were making the journey and approaching the city, Peter ascended to the upper rooms, so that he might pray, at about the sixth hour.
verses.textLa: Postera autem die iter illis facientibus, et appropinquantibus civitati, ascendit Petrus in superiora ut oraret circa horam sextam.

verses.textEn: And since he was hungry, he wanted to enjoy some food. Then, as they were preparing it, an ecstasy of mind fell over him.
verses.textLa: Et cum esuriret, voluit gustare. Parantibus autem illis, cecidit super eum mentis excessus:

verses.textEn: And he saw heaven opened, and a certain container descending, as if a great linen sheet were let down, by its four corners, from heaven to earth,
verses.textLa: et vidit cælum apertum, et descendens vas quoddam, velut linteum magnum, quattuor initiis submitti de cælo in terram,

verses.textEn: on which were all four-footed beasts, and the crawling things of the earth and the flying things of the air.
verses.textLa: in quo erant omnia quadrupedia, et serpentia terræ, et volatilia cæli.

verses.textEn: And a voice came to him: “Rise up, Peter! Kill and eat.”
verses.textLa: Et facta est vox ad eum: Surge Petre, occide, et manduca.

verses.textEn: But Peter said: “Far be it from me, lord. For I have never eaten anything common or unclean.”
verses.textLa: Ait autem Petrus: Absit Domine, quia numquam manducavi omne commune, et immundum.

verses.textEn: And the voice, again a second time to him: “What God has purified, you shall not call common.”
verses.textLa: Et vox iterum secundo ad eum: Quod Deus purificavit, tu commune ne dixeris.

verses.textEn: Now this was done three times. And immediately the container was taken up to heaven.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem factum est per ter: et statim receptum est vas in cælum.

verses.textEn: Now while Peter was still hesitant within himself as to what the vision, which he had seen, might mean, behold, the men who had been sent from Cornelius stood at the gate, inquiring about Simon’s house.
verses.textLa: Et dum intra se hæsitaret Petrus quidnam esset visio, quam vidisset: ecce viri, qui missi erant a Cornelio, inquirentes domum Simonis, astiterunt ad ianuam.

verses.textEn: And when they had called out, they asked if Simon, who is surnamed Peter, was a guest in that place.
verses.textLa: Et cum vocassent, interrogabant, si Simon, qui cognominatur Petrus, illic haberet hospitium.

verses.textEn: Then, as Peter was thinking about the vision, the Spirit said to him, “Behold, three men seek you.
verses.textLa: Petro autem cogitante de visione, dixit Spiritus ei: Ecce viri tres quærunt te.

verses.textEn: And so, rise up, descend, and go with them, doubting nothing. For I have sent them.”
verses.textLa: Surge itaque, descende, et vade cum eis nihil dubitans: quia ego misi illos.

verses.textEn: Then Peter, descending to the men, said: “Behold, I am the one whom you seek. What is the reason for which you have arrived?”
verses.textLa: Descendens autem Petrus ad viros, dixit: Ecce ego sum, quem quæritis: quæ causa est, propter quam venistis?

verses.textEn: And they said: “Cornelius, a centurion, a just and God-fearing man, who has good testimony from the entire nation of the Jews, received a message from a holy Angel to summon you to his house and to listen to words from you.”
verses.textLa: Qui dixerunt: Cornelius Centurio, vir iustus, et timens Deum, et testimonium habens ab universa gente Iudæorum, responsum accepit ab Angelo sancto accersire te in domum suam, et audire verba abs te.

verses.textEn: Therefore, leading them in, he received them as guests. Then, on following the day, rising up, he set out with them. And some of the brothers from Joppa accompanied him.
verses.textLa: Introducens ergo eos, recepit hospitio. Sequenti autem die surgens profectus est cum illis: et quidam ex fratribus ab Ioppe comitati sunt eum.

verses.textEn: And on the next day, he entered Caesarea. And truly, Cornelius was waiting for them, having called together his family and closest friends.
verses.textLa: Altera autem die introivit Cæsaream. Cornelius vero expectabat illos, convocatis cognatis suis, et necessariis amicis.

verses.textEn: And it happened that, when Peter had entered, Cornelius went to meet him. And falling before his feet, he reverenced.
verses.textLa: Et factum est cum introisset Petrus, obvius venit ei Cornelius, et procidens ad pedes eius adoravit.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Peter, lifting him up, said: “Rise up, for I also am only a man.”
verses.textLa: Petrus vero elevavit eum, dicens: Surge, et ego ipse homo sum.

verses.textEn: And speaking with him, he entered, and he found many who had gathered together.
verses.textLa: Et loquens cum illo intravit, et invenit multos, qui convenerant:

verses.textEn: And he said to them: “You know how abominable it would be for a Jewish man to be joined with, or to be added to, a foreign people. But God has revealed to me to call no man common or unclean.
verses.textLa: dixitque ad illos: Vos scitis quomodo abominatum sit viro Iudæo coniungi, aut accedere ad alienigenam: sed mihi ostendit Deus, neminem communem aut immundum dicere hominem.

verses.textEn: Because of this and without doubt, I came when summoned. Therefore, I ask you, for what reason have you summoned me?”
verses.textLa: Propter quod sine dubitatione veni accersitus. Interrogo ergo, quam ob causam accersistis me?

verses.textEn: And Cornelius said: “It is now the fourth day, to this very hour, since I was praying in my house at the ninth hour, and behold, a man stood before me in a white vestment, and he said:
verses.textLa: Et Cornelius ait: A nudiusquarta die usque ad hanc horam, orans eram hora nona in domo mea, et ecce vir stetit ante me in veste candida, et ait:

verses.textEn: ‘Cornelius, your prayer has been heard and your almsgiving has been remembered in the sight of God.
verses.textLa: Corneli, exaudita est oratio tua, et eleemosynæ tuæ commemoratæ sunt in conspectu Dei.

verses.textEn: Therefore, send to Joppa and summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter. This man is a guest in the house of Simon, a tanner, near the sea.’
verses.textLa: Mitte ergo in Ioppen, et accersi Simonem, qui cognominatur Petrus: hic hospitatur in domo Simonis coriarii iuxta mare.

verses.textEn: And so, I promptly sent for you. And you have done well in coming here. Therefore, all of us are now present in your sight to hear all the things that were taught to you by the Lord.”
verses.textLa: Confestim ergo misi ad te: et tu benefecisti veniendo. Nunc ergo omnes nos in conspectu tuo adsumus audire omnia quæcumque tibi præcepta sunt a Domino.

verses.textEn: Then, Peter, opening his mouth, said: “I have concluded in truth that God is not a respecter of persons.
verses.textLa: Aperiens autem Petrus os suum, dixit: In veritate comperi quia non est personarum acceptor Deus,

verses.textEn: But within every nation, whoever fears him and works justice is acceptable to him.
verses.textLa: sed in omni gente qui timet eum, et operatur iustitiam, acceptus est illi.

verses.textEn: God sent the Word to the sons of Israel, announcing the peace through Jesus Christ, for he is the Lord of all.
verses.textLa: Verbum misit Deus filiis Israel, annuncians pacem per Iesum Christum: (hic est omnium Dominus.)

verses.textEn: You know that the Word has been made known throughout all Judea. For beginning from Galilee, after the baptism which John preached,
verses.textLa: Vos scitis quod factum est verbum per universam Iudæum: incipiens enim a Galilæa post baptismum, quod prædicavit Ioannes,

verses.textEn: Jesus of Nazareth, whom God anointed with the Holy Spirit and with power, traveled around doing good and healing all those oppressed by the devil. For God was with him.
verses.textLa: Iesum a Nazareth: quomodo unxit eum Deus Spiritu Sancto, et virtute, qui pertransiit benefaciendo, et sanando omnes oppressos a diabolo, quoniam Deus erat cum illo.

verses.textEn: And we are witnesses of all that he did in the region of Judea and in Jerusalem, he whom they killed by hanging him on a tree.
verses.textLa: Et nos testes sumus omnium, quæ fecit in regione Iudæorum, et Ierusalem, quem occiderunt suspendentes in ligno.

verses.textEn: God raised him up on the third day and permitted him to be made manifest,
verses.textLa: Hunc Deus suscitavit tertia die, et dedit eum manifestum fieri

verses.textEn: not to all the people, but to the witnesses preordained by God, to those of us who ate and drank with him after he rose again from the dead.
verses.textLa: non omni populo, sed testibus præordinatis a Deo: nobis, qui manducavimus, et bibimus cum illo postquam resurrexit a mortuis.

verses.textEn: And he instructed us to preach to the people, and to testify that he is the One who was appointed by God to be the judge of the living and of the dead.
verses.textLa: Et præcepit nobis prædicare populo, et testificari quia ipse est, qui constitutus est a Deo iudex vivorum, et mortuorum.

verses.textEn: To him all the Prophets offer testimony that through his name all who believe in him receive the remission of sins.”
verses.textLa: Huic omnes Prophetæ testimonium perhibent remissionem peccatorum accipere per nomen eius omnes, qui credunt in eum.

verses.textEn: While Peter was still speaking these words, the Holy Spirit fell over all of those who were listening to the Word.
verses.textLa: Adhuc loquente Petro verba hæc, cecidit Spiritus Sanctus super omnes, qui audiebant verbum.

verses.textEn: And the faithful of the circumcision, who had arrived with Peter, were astonished that the grace of the Holy Spirit was also poured out upon the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Et obstupuerunt ex circumcisione fideles, qui venerant cum Petro: quia et in nationes gratia Spiritus Sancti effusa est.

verses.textEn: For they heard them speaking in tongues and magnifying God.
verses.textLa: Audiebant enim illos loquentes linguis, et magnificantes Deum.

verses.textEn: Then Peter responded, “How could anyone prohibit water, so that those who have received the Holy Spirit would not be baptized, just as we also have been?”
verses.textLa: Tunc respondit Petrus: Numquid aquam quis prohibere potest ut non baptizentur hi, qui Spiritum Sanctum acceperunt sicut et nos?

verses.textEn: And he ordered them to be baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus Christ. Then they begged him to remain with them for some days.
verses.textLa: Et iussit eos baptizari in nomine Domini Iesu Christi. Tunc rogaverunt eum ut maneret apud eos aliquot diebus.
verses.notes: The earliest valid Sacrament of Baptism was in the name of Jesus, probably without the Trinitarian formula. But the Church has authority over the Sacraments, even concerning certain conditions for validity, so that today, the Trinitarian formula is generally required for a valid Baptism.

verses.textEn: Now the Apostles and brothers who were in Judea heard that the Gentiles had also received the Word of God.
verses.textLa: Audierunt autem Apostoli, et fratres, qui erant in Iudæa: quoniam et Gentes receperunt verbum Dei.

verses.textEn: Then, when Peter had gone up to Jerusalem, those who were of the circumcision argued against him,
verses.textLa: Cum autem ascendisset Petrus Ierosolymam, disceptabant adversus illum, qui erant ex circumcisione,

verses.textEn: saying, “Why did you enter to uncircumcised men, and why did you eat with them?”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Quare introisti ad viros præputium habentes, et manducasti cum illis?

verses.textEn: And Peter began to explain to them, in an orderly manner, saying:
verses.textLa: Incipiens autem Petrus exponebat illis ordinem, dicens:

verses.textEn: “I was in the city of Joppa praying, and I saw, in an ecstasy of mind, a vision: a certain container descending, like a great linen sheet being let down from heaven by its four corners. And it drew near to me.
verses.textLa: Ego eram in civitate Ioppe orans, et vidi in excessu mentis visionem, descendens vas quoddam velut linteum magnum quattuor initiis summitti de cælo, et venit usque ad me.

verses.textEn: And looking into it, I considered and saw the four-footed beasts of the earth, and the wild beasts, and the reptiles, and the flying things of the air.
verses.textLa: In quod intuens considerabam, et vidi quadrupedia terræ, et bestias, et reptilia, et volatilia cæli.

verses.textEn: Then I also heard a voice saying to me: ‘Rise up, Peter. Kill and eat.’
verses.textLa: Audivi autem et vocem dicentem mihi: Surge Petre, occide, et manduca.

verses.textEn: But I said: ‘Never, lord! For what is common or unclean has never entered into my mouth.’
verses.textLa: Dixi autem: Nequaquam Domine: quia commune aut immundum numquam introivit in os meum.

verses.textEn: Then the voice responded a second time from heaven, ‘What God has cleansed, you shall not call common.’
verses.textLa: Respondit autem vox secundo de cælo: Quæ Deus mundavit, tu ne commune dixeris.

verses.textEn: Now this was done three times. And then everything was taken up again into heaven.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem factum est per ter: et recepta sunt omnia rursum in cælum.

verses.textEn: And behold, immediately there were three men standing near the house where I was, having been sent to me from Caesarea.
verses.textLa: Et ecce viri tres confestim astiterunt in domo, in qua eram, missi a Cæsarea ad me.

verses.textEn: Then the Spirit told me that I should go with them, doubting nothing. And these six brothers went with me also. And we entered into the house of the man.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Spiritus mihi ut irem cum illis, nihil hæsitans. Venerunt autem mecum et sex fratres isti, et ingressi sumus in domum viri.

verses.textEn: And he described for us how he had seen an Angel in his house, standing and saying to him: ‘Send to Joppa and summon Simon, who is surnamed Peter.
verses.textLa: Narravit autem nobis, quomodo vidisset Angelum in domo sua, stantem et dicentem sibi: Mitte in Ioppen, et accersi Simonem, qui cognominatur Petrus,

verses.textEn: And he shall speak to you words, by which you shall be saved with your whole house.’
verses.textLa: qui loquetur tibi verba, in quibus salvus eris tu, et universa domus tua.

verses.textEn: And when I had begun to speak, the Holy Spirit fell upon them, just as upon us also, in the beginning.
verses.textLa: Cum autem cœpissem loqui, cecidit Spiritus Sanctus super eos, sicut et in nos in initio.

verses.textEn: Then I remembered the words of the Lord, just as he himself said: ‘John, indeed, baptized with water, but you shall be baptized with the Holy Spirit.’
verses.textLa: Recordatus sum autem verbi Domini, sicut dicebat: Ioannes quidem baptizavit aqua, vos autem baptizabimini Spiritu Sancto.

verses.textEn: Therefore, if God gave them the same grace, as also to us, who have believed in the Lord Jesus Christ, who was I, that I would be able to prohibit God?”
verses.textLa: Si ergo eamdem gratiam dedit illis Deus, sicut et nobis, qui credidimus in Dominum Iesum Christum: ego quis eram, qui possem prohibere Deum?

verses.textEn: Having heard these things, they were silent. And they glorified God, saying: “So has God also given to the Gentiles repentance unto life.”
verses.textLa: His auditis, tacuerunt: et glorificaverunt Deum, dicentes: Ergo et Gentibus pœnitentiam dedit Deus ad vitam.

verses.textEn: And some of them, having been dispersed by the persecution that had occurred under Stephen, traveled around, even to Phoenicia and Cyprus and Antioch, speaking the Word to no one, except to Jews only.
verses.textLa: Et illi quidem, qui dispersi fuerant a tribulatione, quæ facta fuerat sub Stephano, perambulaverunt usque Phœnicen, et Cyprum, et Antiochiam, nemini loquentes verbum, nisi solis Iudæis.

verses.textEn: But some of these men from Cyprus and Cyrene, when they had entered into Antioch, were speaking also to the Greeks, announcing the Lord Jesus.
verses.textLa: Erant autem quidam ex eis viri Cyprii, et Cyrenæi, qui cum introissent Antiochiam, loquebantur et ad Græcos, annunciantes Dominum Iesum.

verses.textEn: And the hand of the Lord was with them. And a great number believed and were converted to the Lord.
verses.textLa: Et erat manus Domini cum eis: multusque numerus credentium conversus est ad Dominum.

verses.textEn: Now the news came to the ears of the Church at Jerusalem about these things, and they sent Barnabas as far as Antioch.
verses.textLa: Pervenit autem sermo ad aures Ecclesiæ, quæ erat Ierosolymis super istis: et miserunt Barnabam usque ad Antiochiam.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived there and had seen the grace of God, he was gladdened. And he exhorted them all to continue in the Lord with a resolute heart.
verses.textLa: Qui cum pervenisset, et vidisset gratiam Dei, gavisus est: et hortabatur omnes in proposito cordis permanere in Domino:

verses.textEn: For he was a good man, and he was filled with the Holy Spirit and with faith. And a great multitude was added to the Lord.
verses.textLa: quia erat vir bonus, et plenus Spiritu Sancto, et fide. Et apposita est multa turba Domino.

verses.textEn: Then Barnabas set out for Tarsus, so that he might seek Saul. And when he had found him, he brought him to Antioch.
verses.textLa: Profectus est autem Barnabas Tarsum, ut quæreret Saulum: quem cum invenisset, perduxit Antiochiam.

verses.textEn: And they were conversing there in the Church for an entire year. And they taught such a great multitude, that it was at Antioch that the disciples were first known by the name of Christian.
verses.textLa: Et annum totum conversati sunt ibi in Ecclesia: et docuerunt turbam multam, ita ut cognominarentur primum Antiochiæ discipuli, Christiani.

verses.textEn: Now in these days, prophets from Jerusalem went over to Antioch.
verses.textLa: In his autem diebus supervenerunt ab Ierosolymis prophetæ Antiochiam:

verses.textEn: And one of them, named Agabus, rising up, signified through the Spirit that there was going to be a great famine over the entire world, which did happen under Claudius.
verses.textLa: et surgens unus ex eis nomine Agabus, significabat per Spiritum famem magnam futuram in universo orbe terrarum, quæ facta est sub Claudio.
verses.notes: Although this famine did occur under Claudius, it will occur more generally over the world, twice. First, during the first part of the tribulation, there will be a severe famine; but this famine will be less harmful in the poorer nations and more harmful in the wealthy nations. Last, there will be a great famine, over nearly the whole world, during the time of the Antichrist’s reign, especially during the last half of that reign.

verses.textEn: Then the disciples declared, according to what each one possessed, what they would offer to be sent to the brothers living in Judea.
verses.textLa: Discipuli autem, prout quis habebat, proposuerunt singuli in ministerium mittere habitantibus in Iudæa fratribus:

verses.textEn: And so they did, sending it to the elders by the hands of Barnabas and Saul.
verses.textLa: quod et fecerunt, mittentes ad seniores per manus Barnabæ, et Sauli.

verses.textEn: Now at the same time, king Herod extended his hand, in order to afflict some from the Church.
verses.textLa: Eodem autem tempore misit Herodes rex manus, ut affligeret quosdam de Ecclesia.

verses.textEn: Then he killed James, the brother of John, with the sword.
verses.textLa: Occidit autem Iacobum fratrem Ioannis gladio.

verses.textEn: And seeing that it pleased the Jews, he set out next to apprehend Peter also. Now it was the days of Unleavened Bread.
verses.textLa: Videns autem quia placeret Iudæis, apposuit ut apprehenderet et Petrum. Erant autem dies Azymorum.

verses.textEn: So when he had apprehended him, he sent him into prison, handing him over into the custody of four groups of four soldiers, intending to produce him to the people after the Passover.
verses.textLa: Quem cum apprehendisset, misit in carcerem, tradens quattuor quaternionibus militum custodiendum, volens post Pascha producere eum populo.

verses.textEn: And so Peter was detained in prison. But prayers were being made without ceasing, by the Church, to God on his behalf.
verses.textLa: Et Petrus quidem servabatur in carcere. Oratio autem fiebant sine intermissione ab Ecclesia ad Deum pro eo.

verses.textEn: And when Herod was ready to produce him, in that same night, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, and was bound with two chains. And there were guards in front of the door, guarding the prison.
verses.textLa: Cum autem producturus eum esset Herodes, in ipsa nocte erat Petrus dormiens inter duos milites, vinctus catenis duabus: et custodes ante ostium custodiebant carcerem.

verses.textEn: And behold, an Angel of the Lord stood near, and a light shined forth in the cell. And tapping Peter on the side, he awakened him, saying, “Rise up, quickly.” And the chains fell from his hands.
verses.textLa: Et ecce Angelus Domini astitit: et lumen refulsit in habitaculo: percussoque latere Petri, excitavit eum, dicens: Surge velociter. Et ceciderunt catenæ de manibus eius.

verses.textEn: Then the Angel said to him: “Dress yourself, and put on your boots.” And he did so. And he said to him, “Wrap your garment around yourself and follow me.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Angelus ad eum: Præcingere, et calcea te caligas tuas. Et fecit sic. Et dixit illi: Circumda tibi vestimentum tuum, et sequere me.
verses.notes: The word ‘caligas’ is ‘boots,’ not ‘sandals.’

verses.textEn: And going out, he followed him. And he did not know this truth: that this was being done by an Angel. For he thought that he was seeing a vision.
verses.textLa: Et exiens sequebatur eum, et nesciebat quia verum est, quod fiebat per Angelum: existimabat enim se visum videre.

verses.textEn: And passing by the first and second guards, they came to the iron gate which leads into the city; and it opened for them by itself. And departing, they continued on along a certain side street. And suddenly the Angel withdrew from him.
verses.textLa: Transeuntes autem primam et secundam custodiam, venerunt ad portam ferream, quæ ducit ad civitatem: quæ ultro aperta est eis. Et exeuntes processerunt vicum unum: et continuo discessit Angelus ab eo.

verses.textEn: And Peter, returning to himself, said: “Now I know, truly, that the Lord sent his Angel, and that he rescued me from the hand of Herod and from all that the people of the Jews were anticipating.”
verses.textLa: Et Petrus ad se reversus, dixit: Nunc scio vere quia misit Dominus Angelum suum, et eripuit me de manu Herodis, et de omni expectatione plebis Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: And as he was considering this, he arrived at the house of Mary, the mother of John, who was surnamed Mark, where many were gathered and were praying.
verses.textLa: Consideransque venit ad domum Mariæ matris Ioannis, qui cognominatus est Marcus, ubi erant multi congregati, et orantes.

verses.textEn: Then, as he knocked at the door of the gate, a girl went out to answer, whose name was Rhoda.
verses.textLa: Pulsante autem eo ostium ianuæ, processit puella ad audiendum, nomine Rhode.

verses.textEn: And when she recognized the voice of Peter, out of joy, she did not open the gate, but instead, running in, she reported that Peter stood before the gate.
verses.textLa: Et ut cognovit vocem Petri, præ gaudio non aperuit ianuam, sed intro currens nunciavit stare Petrum ante ianuam.

verses.textEn: But they said to her, “You are crazy.” But she reaffirmed that this was so. Then they were saying, “It is his angel.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt ad eam: Insanis. Illa autem affirmabat sic se habere. Illi autem dicebant: angelus eius est.
verses.notes: They did not mean literally, an angel, but his ghost (so they thought).

verses.textEn: But Peter was persevering in knocking. And when they had opened, they saw him and were astonished.
verses.textLa: Petrus autem perseverabat pulsans. Cum autem aperuissent, viderunt eum, et obstupuerunt.

verses.textEn: But motioning to them with his hand to be silent, he explained how the Lord had led him away from prison. And he said, “Inform James and those brothers.” And going out, he went away to another place.
verses.textLa: Annuens autem eis manu ut tacerent, narravit quomodo Dominus eduxisset eum de carcere, dixitque: Nunciate Iacobo, et fratribus hæc. Et egressus abiit in alium locum.

verses.textEn: Then, when daylight came, there was no small commotion among the soldiers, as to what had happened concerning Peter.
verses.textLa: Facta autem die, erat non parva turbatio inter milites, quidnam factum esset de Petro.

verses.textEn: And when Herod had requested him and did not obtain him, having had the guards interrogated, he ordered them led away. And descending from Judea into Caesarea, he lodged there.
verses.textLa: Herodes autem cum requisisset eum, et non invenisset, inquisitione facta de custodibus, iussit eos duci: descendensque a Iudæa in Cæsaream, ibi commoratus est.

verses.textEn: Now he was angry with those of Tyre and Sidon. But they came to him with one accord, and, having persuaded Blastus, who was over the bedchamber of the king, they petitioned for peace, because their regions were supplied with food by him.
verses.textLa: Erat autem iratus Tyriis, et Sidonis. At illi unanimes venerunt ad eum, et persuaso Blasto, qui erat super cubiculum regis, postulabant pacem, eo quod alerentur regiones eorum ab illo.

verses.textEn: Then, on the appointed day, Herod was clothed in kingly apparel, and he sat in the judgment seat, and he gave a speech to them.
verses.textLa: Statuto autem die Herodes vestitus veste regia, sedit pro tribunali, et concionabatur ad eos.

verses.textEn: Then the people were crying out, “The voice of a god, and not of a man!”
verses.textLa: Populus autem acclamabat: Dei voces, et non hominis!

verses.textEn: And immediately, an Angel of the Lord struck him down, because he had not given honor to God. And having been consumed by worms, he expired.
verses.textLa: Confestim autem percussit eum Angelus Domini, eo quod non dedisset honorem Deo: et consumptus a vermibus, expiravit.

verses.textEn: But the word of the Lord was increasing and multiplying.
verses.textLa: Verbum autem Domini crescebat, et multiplicabatur.

verses.textEn: Then Barnabas and Saul, having completed the ministry, returned from Jerusalem, bringing with them John, who was surnamed Mark.
verses.textLa: Barnabas autem et Saulus reversi sunt ab Ierosolymis expleto ministerio, assumpto Ioanne, qui cognominatus est Marcus.

verses.textEn: Now there were, in the Church at Antioch, prophets and teachers, among whom were Barnabas, and Simon, who was called the Black, and Lucius of Cyrene, and Manahen, who was the foster brother of Herod the tetrarch, and Saul.
verses.textLa: Erant autem in Ecclesia, quæ erat Antiochiæ, prophetæ, et doctores, in quibus Barnabas, et Simon, qui vocabatur Niger, et Lucius Cyrenensis, et Manahen, qui erat Herodis Tetrarchæ collactaneus, et Saulus.

verses.textEn: Now as they were ministering for the Lord and fasting, the Holy Spirit said to them: “Separate Saul and Barnabas for me, for the work for which I have selected them.”
verses.textLa: Ministrantibus autem illis Domino, et ieiunantibus, dixit illis Spiritus Sanctus: Segregate mihi Saulum, et Barnabam in opus, ad quod assumpsi eos.

verses.textEn: Then, fasting and praying and imposing their hands upon them, they sent them away.
verses.textLa: Tunc ieiunantes, et orantes, imponentesque eis manus, dimiserunt illos.

verses.textEn: And having been sent by the Holy Spirit, they went to Seleucia. And from there they sailed to Cyprus.
verses.textLa: Et ipsi quidem missi a Spiritu Sancto abierunt Seleuciam; et inde navigaverunt Cyprum.

verses.textEn: And when they had arrived at Salamis, they were preaching the Word of God in the synagogues of the Jews. And they also had John in the ministry.
verses.textLa: Et cum venissent Salaminam, prædicabant verbum Dei in synagogis Iudæorum. Habebant autem et Ioannem in ministerio.

verses.textEn: And when they had traveled throughout the entire island, even to Paphos, they found a certain man, a magician, a false prophet, a Jew, whose name was Bar-Jesu.
verses.textLa: Et cum perambulassent universam insulam usque ad Paphum, invenerunt quendam virum magum pseudoprophetam, Iudæum, cui nomen erat Bariesu,

verses.textEn: And he was with the proconsul, Sergius Paulus, a prudent man. This man, summoning Barnabas and Saul, wanted to hear the Word of God.
verses.textLa: qui erat cum Proconsule Sergio Paulo viro prudente. Hic, accersitis Barnaba, et Saulo, desiderabat audire verbum Dei.

verses.textEn: But Elymas the magician (for so his name is translated) stood against them, seeking to turn the proconsul away from the Faith.
verses.textLa: Resistebat autem illis Elymas magus, (si enim interpretatur nomen eius) quærens avertere Proconsulem a fide.

verses.textEn: Then Saul, who is also called Paul, having been filled with the Holy Spirit, looked intently at him,
verses.textLa: Saulus autem, qui et Paulus, repletus Spiritu Sancto, intuens in eum,

verses.textEn: and he said: “So full of every deceit and of all falsehoods, son of the devil, enemy of all justice, you never cease to subvert the righteous ways of the Lord!
verses.textLa: dixit: O plene omni dolo, et omni fallacia, fili diaboli, inimice omnis iustitiæ, non desinis subvertere vias Domini rectas.

verses.textEn: And now, behold, the hand of the Lord is upon you. And you will be blinded, not seeing the sun for a length of time.” And immediately a fog and a darkness fell over him. And wandering around, he was seeking someone who might lead him by the hand.
verses.textLa: Et nunc ecce manus Domini super te, et eris cæcus, non videns solem usque ad tempus. Et confestim cecidit in eum caligo, et tenebræ, et circuiens quærebat qui ei manum daret.

verses.textEn: Then the proconsul, when he had seen what was done, believed, being in wonder over the doctrine of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Tunc Proconsul cum vidisset factum, credidit admirans super doctrina Domini.

verses.textEn: And when Paul and those who were with him had sailed from Paphos, they arrived at Perga in Pamphylia. Then John departed from them and returned to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et cum a Papho navigassent Paulus, et qui cum eo erant, venerunt Pergen Pamphyliæ. Ioannes autem discedens ab eis, reversus est Ierosolymam.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, they, traveling on from Perga, arrived at Antioch in Pisidia. And upon entering the synagogue on the Sabbath day, they sat down.
verses.textLa: Illi vero pertranseuntes Pergen, venerunt Antiochiam Pisidiæ: et ingressi synagogam die Sabbatorum, sederunt.

verses.textEn: Then, after the reading from the Law and the Prophets, the leaders of the synagogue sent to them, saying: “Noble brothers, if there is in you any word of exhortation to the people, speak.”
verses.textLa: Post lectionem autem legis, et Prophetarum, miserunt principes synagogæ ad eos, dicentes: Viri fratres, si quis est in vobis sermo exhortationis ad plebem, dicite.

verses.textEn: Then Paul, rising up and motioning for silence with his hand, said: “Men of Israel and you who fear God, listen closely.
verses.textLa: Surgens autem Paulus, et manu silentium indicens, ait: Viri Israelitæ, et qui timetis Deum, audite:

verses.textEn: The God of the people of Israel chose our fathers, and exalted the people, when they were settlers in the land of Egypt. And with an exalted arm, he led them away from there.
verses.textLa: Deus plebis Israel elegit patres nostros, et plebem exaltavit cum essent incolæ in terra Ægypti, et in brachio excelso eduxit eos ex ea,

verses.textEn: And throughout a time of forty years, he endured their behavior in the desert.
verses.textLa: et per quadraginta annorum tempus mores eorum sustinuit in deserto.

verses.textEn: And by destroying seven nations in the land of Canaan, he divided their land among them by lot,
verses.textLa: Et destruens gentes septem in terra Chanaan, sorte distribuit eis terram eorum,

verses.textEn: after about four hundred and fifty years. And after these things, he gave them judges, even until the prophet Samuel.
verses.textLa: quasi post quadringentos et quinquaginta annos: et post hæc dedit iudices, usque ad Samuel Prophetam.

verses.textEn: And later on, they petitioned for a king. And God gave them Saul, the son of Kish, a man from the tribe of Benjamin, for forty years.
verses.textLa: Et exinde postulaverunt regem: et dedit illis Deus Saul filium Cis, virum de tribu Beniamin, annis quadraginta.

verses.textEn: And having removed him, he raised up for them king David. And offering testimony about him, he said, ‘I have found David, the son of Jesse, to be a man according to my own heart, who will accomplish all that I will.’
verses.textLa: Et amoto illo, suscitavit illis David regem: cui testimonium perhibens, dixit: Inveni David filium Iesse, virum secundum cor meum, qui faciet omnes voluntates meas.

verses.textEn: From his offspring, according to the Promise, God has brought Jesus the Savior to Israel.
verses.textLa: Huius Deus ex semine secundum Promissionem eduxit Israel salvatorem Iesum,

verses.textEn: John was preaching, before the face of his advent, a baptism of repentance to all the people of Israel.
verses.textLa: prædicante Ioanne ante faciem adventus eius baptismum pœnitentiæ omni populo Israel.

verses.textEn: Then, when John completed his course, he was saying: ‘I am not the one you consider me to be. For behold, one arrives after me, the shoes of whose feet I am not worthy to loosen.’
verses.textLa: Cum impleret autem Ioannes cursum suum, dicebat: Quem me arbitramini esse, non sum ego, sed ecce venit post me, cuius non sum dignus calceamenta pedum solvere.

verses.textEn: Noble brothers, sons of the stock of Abraham, and those among you who fear God, it is to you the Word of this salvation has been sent.
verses.textLa: Viri fratres, filii generis Abraham, et qui in vobis timent Deum, vobis verbum salutis huius missum est.
verses.notes: In the synagogues in that time period there would typically be some Hebrews (descendents of Abraham) and also some new converts to the Jewish faith, who were not of Hebrew descent. These latter Paul refers to as those who fear God.

verses.textEn: For those who were living in Jerusalem, and its rulers, heeding neither him, nor the voices of the Prophets that are read on every Sabbath, fulfilled these by judging him.
verses.textLa: Qui enim habitabant Ierusalem, et principes eius hunc ignorantes, et voces prophetarum, quæ per omne sabbatum leguntur, iudicantes impleverunt,

verses.textEn: And although they found no case for death against him, they petitioned Pilate, so that they might put him to death.
verses.textLa: et nullam causam mortis invenientes in eo, petierunt a Pilato, ut interficerent eum.

verses.textEn: And when they had fulfilled everything that had been written about him, taking him down from the tree, they placed him in a tomb.
verses.textLa: Cumque consummassent omnia, quæ de eo scripta erant, deponentes eum de ligno, posuerunt eum in monumento.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, God raised him up from the dead on the third day.
verses.textLa: Deus vero suscitavit eum a mortuis tertia die:

verses.textEn: And he was seen for many days by those who went up with him from Galilee to Jerusalem, who even now are his witnesses to the people.
verses.textLa: qui visus est per dies multos his, qui simul ascenderant cum eo de Galilæa in Ierusalem: qui usque nunc sunt testes eius ad plebem.

verses.textEn: And we are announcing to you that the Promise, which was made to our fathers,
verses.textLa: Et nos vobis annunciamus eam, quæ ad patres nostros repromissio facta est:

verses.textEn: has been fulfilled by God for our children by raising up Jesus, just as it has been written in the second Psalm also: ‘You are my Son. This day I have begotten you.’
verses.textLa: quoniam hanc Deus adimplevit filiis nostris resuscitans Iesum, sicut et in Psalmo secundo scriptum est: Filius meus es tu, ego hodie genui te.

verses.textEn: Now, since he raised him from the dead, so as to no longer return to corruption, he has said this: ‘I will give to you the holy things of David, the faithful one.’
verses.textLa: Quod autem suscitavit eum a mortuis, amplius iam non reversurum in corruptionem, ita dixit: Quia dabo vobis sancta David fidelia.

verses.textEn: And also then, in another place, he says: ‘You will not allow your Holy One to see corruption.’
verses.textLa: Ideoque et alias dicit: Non dabis Sanctum tuum videre corruptionem.

verses.textEn: For David, when he had ministered to his generation in accordance with the will of God, fell asleep, and he was placed next to his fathers, and he saw corruption.
verses.textLa: David enim in sua generatione cum administrasset, voluntati Dei dormivit: et appositus est ad patres suos, et vidit corruptionem.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, he whom God has raised from the dead has not seen corruption.
verses.textLa: Quem vero Deus suscitavit a mortuis, non vidit corruptionem.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let it be known to you, noble brothers, that through him is announced to you remission from sins and from everything by which you were not able to be justified in the law of Moses.
verses.textLa: Notum igitur sit vobis viri fratres, quia per hunc vobis remissio peccatorum annunciatur, et ab omnibus, quibus non potuistis in lege Moysi iustificari,

verses.textEn: In him, all who believe are justified.
verses.textLa: in hoc omnis, qui credit, iustificatur.

verses.textEn: Therefore, be careful, lest what was said by the Prophets may overwhelm you:
verses.textLa: Videte ergo ne superveniat vobis quod dictum est in Prophetis:

verses.textEn: ‘You despisers! Look, and wonder, and be scattered! For I am working a deed in your days, a deed which you would not believe, even if someone were to explain it to you.’ ”
verses.textLa: Videte contemptores, et admiramini, et disperdimini: quia opus operor ego in diebus vestris, opus quod non credetis, si quis enarraverit vobis.

verses.textEn: Then, as they were departing, they asked them if, on the following Sabbath, they might speak these words to them.
verses.textLa: Exeuntibus autem illis rogabant ut sequenti Sabbato loquerentur sibi verba hæc.

verses.textEn: And when the synagogue had been dismissed, many among the Jews and the new worshipers were following Paul and Barnabas. And they, speaking to them, persuaded them to continue in the grace of God.
verses.textLa: Cumque dimissa esset synagoga, secuti sunt multi Iudæorum, et colentium advenarum, Paulum, et Barnabam: qui loquentes suadebant eis ut permanerent in gratia Dei.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, on the following Sabbath, nearly the entire city came together to hear the Word of God.
verses.textLa: Sequenti vero Sabbato pene universa civitas convenit audire verbum Dei.

verses.textEn: Then the Jews, seeing the crowds, were filled with envy, and they, blaspheming, contradicted the things that were being said by Paul.
verses.textLa: Videntes autem turbas Iudæi, repleti sunt zelo, et contradicebant his, quæ a Paulo dicebantur, blasphemantes.

verses.textEn: Then Paul and Barnabas said firmly: “It was necessary to speak the Word of God first to you. But because you reject it, and so judge yourselves unworthy of eternal life, behold, we turn to the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Tunc constanter Paulus et Barnabas dixerunt: Vobis oportebat primum loqui verbum Dei: sed quoniam repellitis illud, et indignos vos iudicatis æternæ vitæ, ecce convertimur ad Gentes.

verses.textEn: For so has the Lord instructed us: ‘I have set you as a light to the Gentiles, so that you may bring salvation to the ends of the earth.’ ”
verses.textLa: Sic enim præcepit nobis Dominus: Posui te in lucem Gentium, ut sis in salutem usque ad extremum terræ.

verses.textEn: Then the Gentiles, upon hearing this, were gladdened, and they were glorifying the Word of the Lord. And as many as believed were preordained to eternal life.
verses.textLa: Audientes autem Gentes gavisæ sunt, et glorificabant verbum Domini: et crediderunt quotquot erant præordinati ad vitam æternam.

verses.textEn: Now the word of the Lord was disseminated throughout the entire region.
verses.textLa: Disseminabatur autem verbum Domini per universam regionem.

verses.textEn: But the Jews incited some devout and honest women, and the leaders of the city. And they stirred up a persecution against Paul and Barnabas. And they drove them away from their parts.
verses.textLa: Iudæi autem concitaverunt mulieres religiosas, et honestas, et primos civitatis, et excitaverunt persecutionem in Paulum, et Barnabam: et eiecerunt eos de finibus suis.

verses.textEn: But they, shaking the dust from their feet against them, went on to Iconium.
verses.textLa: At illi excusso pulvere pedum in eos, venerunt Iconium.

verses.textEn: The disciples were likewise filled with gladness and with the Holy Spirit.
verses.textLa: Discipuli quoque replebantur gaudio, et Spiritu Sancto.

verses.textEn: Now it happened in Iconium that they entered together into the synagogue of the Jews, and they spoke in such a way that a copious multitude of both Jews and Greeks believed.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem Iconii, ut simul introirent in synagogam Iudæorum, et loquerentur, ita ut crederet Iudæorum, et Græcorum copiosa multitudo.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the Jews who were unbelieving had incited and enflamed the souls of the Gentiles against the brothers.
verses.textLa: Qui vero increduli fuerunt Iudæi, suscitaverunt, et ad iracundiam concitaverunt animas Gentium adversus fratres.

verses.textEn: And so, they remained for a long time, acting faithfully in the Lord, offering testimony to the Word of his grace, providing signs and wonders done by their hands.
verses.textLa: Multo igitur tempore demorati sunt, fiducialiter agentes in Domino, testimonium perhibente verbo gratiæ suæ, dante signa, et prodigia fieri per manus eorum.

verses.textEn: Then the multitude of the city was divided. And certainly, some were with the Jews, yet truly others were with the Apostles.
verses.textLa: Divisa est autem multitudo civitatis: et quidam quidem erant cum Iudæis, quidam vero cum Apostolis.

verses.textEn: Now when an assault had been planned by the Gentiles and the Jews with their leaders, so that they might treat them with contempt and stone them,
verses.textLa: Cum autem factus esset impetus Gentilium, et Iudæorum cum principibus suis, ut contumeliis afficerent, et lapidarent eos,
verses.notes: Literally, the text says ‘an assault of the Gentiles and Jews,’ but the meaning is that Gentiles and Jews were the ones planning the assault, so the translation rephrases to make this clear. Also, the verb ‘factus esset’ might seem to mean that they had already made such an assault, but instead the meaning is that they made a plan to carry out the assault. So the most literal translation is not always the most accurate.

verses.textEn: they, realizing this, fled together to Lystra and Derbe, cities of Lycaonia, and to the entire surrounding region. And they were evangelizing in that place.
verses.textLa: intelligentes confugerunt ad civitates Lycaoniæ Lystram, et Derben, et universam in circuitu regionem, et ibi evangelizantes erant.

verses.textEn: And a certain man was sitting at Lystra, disabled in his feet, lame from his mother’s womb, who had never walked.
verses.textLa: Et quidam vir Lystris infirmus pedibus sedebat, claudus ex utero matris suæ, qui numquam ambulaverat.

verses.textEn: This man heard Paul speaking. And Paul, gazing at him intently, and perceiving that he had faith, so that he might be healed,
verses.textLa: Hic audivit Paulum loquentem. Qui intuitus eum, et videns quia fidem haberet ut salvus fieret,

verses.textEn: said with a loud voice, “Stand upright upon your feet!” And he leaped up and walked around.
verses.textLa: dixit magna voce: Surge super pedes tuos rectus. Et exilivit, et ambulabat.

verses.textEn: But when the crowds had seen what Paul had done, they lifted up their voice in the Lycaonian language, saying, “The gods, having taken the likenesses of men, have descended to us!”
verses.textLa: Turbæ autem cum vidissent quod fecerat Paulus, levaverunt vocem suam Lycaonice, dicentes: Quia dii similes facti hominibus, descenderunt ad nos.

verses.textEn: And they called Barnabas, ‘Jupiter,’ yet truly they called Paul, ‘Mercury,’ because he was the lead speaker.
verses.textLa: Et vocabant Barnabam Iovem, Paulum vero Mercurium: quoniam ipse erat dux verbi.

verses.textEn: Also, the priest of Jupiter, who was outside the city, in front of the gate, bringing in oxen and garlands, was willing to offer sacrifice with the people.
verses.textLa: Sacerdos quoque Iovis, qui erat ante civitatem, tauros, et coronas ante ianuas afferens, cum populis volebat sacrificare.

verses.textEn: And as soon as the Apostles, Barnabas and Paul, had heard this, tearing their tunics, they leapt into the crowd, crying out
verses.textLa: Quod ubi audierunt Apostoli, Barnabas et Paulus, conscissis tunicis suis exilierunt in turbas clamantes,

verses.textEn: and saying: “Men, why would you do this? We also are mortals, men like yourselves, preaching to you to be converted, from these vain things, to the living God, who made heaven and earth and the sea and all that is in them.
verses.textLa: et dicentes: Viri, quid hæc facitis? Et nos mortales sumus, similes vobis homines, annunciantes vobis ab his vanis converti ad Deum vivum, qui fecit cælum, et terram, et mare, et omnia quæ in eis sunt:

verses.textEn: In previous generations, he permitted all nations to walk in their own ways.
verses.textLa: qui in præteritis generationibus dimisit omnes gentes ingredi vias suas.

verses.textEn: But certainly, he did not leave himself without testimony, doing good from heaven, giving rains and fruitful seasons, filling their hearts with food and gladness.”
verses.textLa: Et quidem non sine testimonio semetipsum reliquit benefaciens de cælo, dans pluvias, et tempora fructifera, implens cibo, et lætitia corda eorum.
verses.notes: Corrected in the Latin and English according to the 1590 Sixtus V edition.

verses.textEn: And by saying these things, they were barely able to restrain the crowds from immolating to them.
verses.textLa: Et hæc dicentes, vix sedaverunt turbas ne sibi immolarent.

verses.textEn: Now certain Jews from Antioch and Iconium arrived there. And having persuaded the crowd, they stoned Paul and dragged him outside of the city, thinking him to be dead.
verses.textLa: Supervenerunt autem quidam ab Antiochia, et Iconio Iudæi: et persuasis turbis, lapidantesque Paulum, traxerunt extra civitatem, existimantes eum mortuum esse.

verses.textEn: But as the disciples were standing around him, he got up and entered the city. And the next day, he set out with Barnabas for Derbe.
verses.textLa: Circumdantibus autem eum discipulis, surgens intravit civitatem, et postera die profectus est cum Barnaba in Derben.

verses.textEn: And when they had evangelized that city, and had taught many, they returned again to Lystra and to Iconium and to Antioch,
verses.textLa: Cumque evangelizassent civitati illi, et docuissent multos, reversi sunt Lystram, et Iconium, et Antiochiam,

verses.textEn: strengthening the souls of the disciples, and exhorting them that they should remain always in the faith, and that it is necessary for us to enter into the kingdom of God through many tribulations.
verses.textLa: confirmantes animas discipulorum, exhortantesque ut permanerent in fide: et quoniam per multas tribulationes oportet nos intrare in regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: And when they had established priests for them in each church, and had prayed with fasting, they commended them to the Lord, in whom they believed.
verses.textLa: Et cum constituissent illis per singulas ecclesias presbyteros, et orassent cum ieiunationibus, commendaverunt eos Domino, in quem crediderunt.

verses.textEn: And traveling by way of Pisidia, they arrived in Pamphylia.
verses.textLa: Transeuntesque Pisidiam, venerunt in Pamphyliam,

verses.textEn: And having spoken the word of the Lord in Perga, they went down into Attalia.
verses.textLa: et loquentes verbum Domini in Perge, descendeunt in Attaliam:

verses.textEn: And from there, they sailed to Antioch, where they had been commended to the grace of God for the work which they had now accomplished.
verses.textLa: et inde navigaverunt Antiochiam, unde erant traditi gratiæ Dei in opus, quod compleverunt.

verses.textEn: And when they had arrived and had gathered together the church, they related what great things God had done with them, and how he had opened the door of faith to the Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venissent, et congregassent Ecclesiam, retulerunt quanta fecisset Deus cum illis, et quia aperuisset Gentibus ostium fidei.

verses.textEn: And they remained for no small amount of time with the disciples.
verses.textLa: Morati sunt autem tempus non modicum cum discipulis.

verses.textEn: And certain ones, descending from Judea, were teaching the brothers, “Unless you are circumcised according to the custom of Moses, you cannot be saved.”
verses.textLa: Et quidam descendentes de Iudæa, docebant fratres: Quia nisi circumcidamini secundum morem Moysi, non potestis salvari.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when Paul and Barnabas made no small uprising against them, they decided that Paul and Barnabas, and some from the opposing side, should go up to the Apostles and priests in Jerusalem concerning this question.
verses.textLa: Facta ergo seditione non minima Paulo, et Barnabæ adversus illos, statuerunt ut ascenderent Paulus, et Barnabas, et quidam alii ex aliis ad Apostolos, et presbyteros in Ierusalem super hac quæstione.

verses.textEn: Therefore, being led by the church, they traveled through Phoenicia and Samaria, describing the conversion of the Gentiles. And they caused great joy among all the brothers.
verses.textLa: Illi ergo deducti ab Ecclesia pertransibant Phœnicen, et Samariam, narrantes conversionem Gentium: et faciebant gaudium magnum omnibus fratribus.

verses.textEn: And when they had arrived in Jerusalem, they were received by the church and the Apostles and the elders, reporting what great things God had done with them.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venissent Ierosolymam, suscepti sunt ab Ecclesia, et ab Apostolis, et senioribus annunciantes quanta Deus fecisset cum illis.

verses.textEn: But some from the sect of the Pharisees, those who were believers, rose up saying, “It is necessary for them to be circumcised and to be instructed to keep the Law of Moses.”
verses.textLa: Surrexerunt autem quidam de hæresi Pharisæorum, qui crediderunt, dicentes: Quia oportet circumcidi eos, præcipere quoque servare legem Moysi.

verses.textEn: And the Apostles and elders came together to take care of this matter.
verses.textLa: Conveneruntque Apostoli, et seniores videre de verbo hoc.

verses.textEn: And after a great contention had taken place, Peter rose up and said to them: “Noble brothers, you know that, in recent days, God has chosen from among us, by my mouth, Gentiles to hear the word of the Gospel and to believe.
verses.textLa: Cum autem magna conquisitio fieret, surgens Petrus dixit ad eos: Viri fratres, vos scitis quoniam ab antiquis diebus Deus in nobis elegit, per os meum audire Gentes verbum Evangelii, et credere.

verses.textEn: And God, who knows hearts, offered testimony, by giving the Holy Spirit to them, just as to us.
verses.textLa: Et qui novit corda Deus, testimonium perhibuit, dans illis Spiritum Sanctum, sicut et nobis,

verses.textEn: And he distinguished nothing between us and them, purifying their hearts by faith.
verses.textLa: et nihil discrevit inter nos et illos, fide purificans corda eorum.

verses.textEn: Now therefore, why do you tempt God to impose a yoke upon the necks of the disciples, which neither our fathers nor we have been able to bear?
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo quid tentatis Deum, imponere iugum super cervices discipulorum, quod neque patres nostri, neque nos portare potuimus?

verses.textEn: But by the grace of the Lord Jesus Christ, we believe in order to be saved, in the same manner also as them.”
verses.textLa: Sed per gratiam Domini Iesu Christi credimus salvari, quemadmodum et illi.

verses.textEn: Then the entire multitude was silent. And they were listening to Barnabas and Paul, describing what great signs and wonders God had wrought among the Gentiles through them.
verses.textLa: Tacuit autem omnis multitudo: et audiebant Barnabam, et Paulum narrantes quanta Deus fecisset signa, et prodigia in Gentibus per eos.

verses.textEn: And after they had been silent, James responded by saying: “Noble brothers, listen to me.
verses.textLa: Et postquam tacuerunt, respondit Iacobus, dicens: Viri fratres, audite me.

verses.textEn: Simon has explained in what manner God first visited, so as to take from the Gentiles a people to his name.
verses.textLa: Simon narravit quemadmodum primum Deus visitavit sumere ex Gentibus populum nomini suo.

verses.textEn: And the words of the Prophets are in agreement with this, just as it was written:
verses.textLa: Et huic concordant verba Prophetarum, sicut scriptum est:

verses.textEn: ‘After these things, I will return, and I will rebuild the tabernacle of David, which has fallen down. And I will rebuild its ruins, and I will raise it up,
verses.textLa: Post hæc revertar, et reædificabo tabernaculum David, quod decidit: et diruta eius reædificabo, et erigam illud:

verses.textEn: so that the rest of men may seek the Lord, along with all the nations over whom my name has been invoked, says the Lord, who does these things.’
verses.textLa: ut requirant ceteri hominum Dominum, et omnes gentes, super quas invocatum est nomen meum, dicit Dominus faciens hæc.

verses.textEn: To the Lord, his own work has been known from eternity.
verses.textLa: Notum a sæculo est Domino opus suum.

verses.textEn: Because of this, I judge that those who were converted to God from among the Gentiles are not to be disturbed,
verses.textLa: Propter quod ego iudico non inquietari eos, qui ex Gentibus convertuntur ad Deum,

verses.textEn: but instead that we write to them, that they should keep themselves from the defilement of idols, and from fornication, and from whatever has been suffocated, and from blood.
verses.textLa: sed scribere ad eos ut abstineant se a contaminationibus simulacrorum, et fornicatione, et suffocatis, et sanguine.

verses.textEn: For Moses, from ancient times, has had in each city those who preach him in the synagogues, where he is read on every Sabbath.”
verses.textLa: Moyses enim a temporibus antiquis habet in singulis civitatibus qui eum prædicent in synagogis, ubi per omne Sabbatum legitur.

verses.textEn: Then it pleased the Apostles and elders, with the whole Church, to choose men from among them, and to send to Antioch, with Paul and Barnabas, and Judas, who was surnamed Barsabbas, and Silas, preeminent men among the brothers,
verses.textLa: Tunc placuit Apostolis, et senioribus cum omni Ecclesia, eligere viros ex eis, et mittere Antiochiam cum Paulo, et Barnaba, Iudam, qui cognominabatur Barsabas, et Silam viros primos in fratribus,

verses.textEn: what was written by their own hands: “The Apostles and elders, brothers, to those who are at Antioch and Syria and Cilicia, brothers from the Gentiles, greetings.
verses.textLa: scribentes per manus eorum: APOSTOLI et seniores fratres, his, qui sunt Antiochiæ, et Syriæ, et Ciliciæ fratribus ex Gentibus, salutem.

verses.textEn: Since we have heard that some, going out from among us, have troubled you with words, subverting your souls, to whom we gave no commandment,
verses.textLa: Quoniam audivimus quia quidam ex nobis exeuntes turbaverunt vos verbis, evertentes animas vestras, quibus non mandavimus:

verses.textEn: it pleased us, being assembled as one, to choose men and to send them to you, with our most beloved Barnabas and Paul:
verses.textLa: placuit nobis collectis in unum, eligere viros, et mittere ad vos cum charissimis nostris Barnaba, et Paulo,

verses.textEn: men who have handed over their lives on behalf of the name of our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: hominibus, qui tradiderunt animas suas pro nomine Domini nostri Iesu Christi.

verses.textEn: Therefore, we have sent Judas and Silas, who themselves also will, with the spoken word, reaffirm to you the same things.
verses.textLa: Misimus ergo Iudam, et Silam, qui et ipsi vobis verbis referent eadem.

verses.textEn: For it has seemed good to the Holy Spirit and to us to impose no further burden upon you, other than these necessary things:
verses.textLa: Visum est enim Spiritui Sancto, et nobis nihil ultra imponere vobis oneris quam hæc necessaria:

verses.textEn: that you abstain from things immolated to idols, and from blood, and from what has been suffocated, and from fornication. You will do well to keep yourselves from these things. Farewell.”
verses.textLa: ut abstineatis vos ab immolatis simulacrorum, et sanguine, et suffocato, et fornicatione, a quibus custodientes vos, bene agetis. Valete.
verses.notes: The figurative meaning of this four-fold prohibition (idols, blood, suffocated bodies of animals, fornication) refers to abstaining from the abomination of desolation, a false Eucharist. The abomination is idolatry, it is blood and meat (but not the true body and blood of Christ), and it is connected with severe sexual immorality.

verses.textEn: And so, having been dismissed, they went down to Antioch. And gathering the multitude together, they delivered the epistle.
verses.textLa: Illi ergo dimissi, descendeunt Antiochiam: et congregata multitudine tradiderunt epistolam.

verses.textEn: And when they had read it, they were gladdened by this consolation.
verses.textLa: Quam cum legissent, gavisi sunt super consolatione.

verses.textEn: But Judas and Silas, being also prophets themselves, consoled the brothers with many words, and they were strengthened.
verses.textLa: Iudas autem, et Silas, et ipsi cum essent prophetæ, verbo plurimo consolati sunt fratres, et confirmaverunt.

verses.textEn: Then, after spending some more time there, they were dismissed with peace, by the brothers, to those who had sent them.
verses.textLa: Facto autem ibi aliquanto tempore, dimissi sunt cum pace a fratribus ad eos, qui miserant illos.

verses.textEn: But it seemed good to Silas to remain there. So Judas alone departed to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Visum est autem Silæ ibi remanere: Iudas autem solus abiit Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And Paul and Barnabas remained at Antioch, with many others, teaching and evangelizing the Word of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Paulus autem, et Barnabas demorabantur Antiochiæ docentes, et evangelizantes cum aliis pluribus verbum Domini.

verses.textEn: Then, after some days, Paul said to Barnabas, “Let us return to visit the brothers throughout all the cities in which we have preached the Word of the Lord, to see how they are.”
verses.textLa: Post aliquot autem dies, dixit ad Barnabam Paulus: Revertentes visitemus fratres per universas civitates, in quibus prædicavimus verbum Domini, quomodo se habeant.

verses.textEn: And Barnabas wanted to take John, who was surnamed Mark, with them also.
verses.textLa: Barnabas autem volebat secum assumere et Ioannem, qui cognominabatur Marcus.

verses.textEn: But Paul was saying that he ought not to be received, since he withdrew from them at Pamphylia, and he had not gone with them in the work.
verses.textLa: Paulus autem rogabat eum (ut qui discessisset ab eis de Pamphylia, et non isset cum eis in opus) non debere recipi.

verses.textEn: And there occurred a dissension, to such an extent that they departed from one another. And Barnabas, indeed taking Mark, sailed to Cyprus.
verses.textLa: Facta est autem dissensio, ita ut discederent ab invicem, et Barnabas quidem assumpto Marco navigaret Cyprum.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Paul, choosing Silas, set out, being delivered by the brothers to the grace of God.
verses.textLa: Paulus vero electo Sila profectus est, traditus gratiæ Dei a fratribus.

verses.textEn: And he traveled through Syria and Cilicia, confirming the Churches, instructing them to keep the precepts of the Apostles and the elders.
verses.textLa: Perambulabat autem Syriam, et Ciliciam, confirmans Ecclesias: præcipiens custodire præcepta Apostolorum, et seniorum.

verses.textEn: Then he arrived at Derbe and Lystra. And behold, a certain disciple named Timothy was there, the son of a faithful Jewish woman, his father a Gentile.
verses.textLa: Pervenit autem Derben, et Lystram. Et ecce discipulus quidam erat ibi nomine Timotheus, filius mulieris Iudææ fidelis, patre Gentili.
verses.notes: It is not clear from the text whether she was faithful to the Jewish faith, or was one of the faithful (i.e. a convert to Christianity).

verses.textEn: The brothers who were at Lystra and Iconium rendered good testimony to him.
verses.textLa: Huic testimonium bonum reddebant qui in Lystris erant, et Iconio fratres.
