verses.textEn: Paul wanted this man to travel with him, and taking him, he circumcised him, because of the Jews who were in those places. For they all knew that his father was a Gentile.
verses.textLa: Hunc voluit Paulus secum proficisci: et assumens circumcidit eum propter Iudæos, qui erant in illis locis. Sciebant enim omnes quod pater eius erat Gentilis.

verses.textEn: And as they were traveling through the cities, they delivered to them the dogmas to be kept, which were decreed by the Apostles and elders who were at Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Cum autem pertransirent civitates, tradebant eis custodiri dogmata, quæ erant decreta ab Apostolis et senioribus, qui erant Ierosolymis.
verses.notes: This decision at Jerusalem, made by Peter and the Apostles and elders (i.e. Bishops), was perhaps the first dogmatic decree of an Ecumenical Council.

verses.textEn: And certainly, the Churches were being strengthened in faith and were increasing in number every day.
verses.textLa: Et Ecclesiæ quidem confirmabantur fide, et abundabunt numero quotidie.

verses.textEn: Then, while crossing through Phrygia and the region of Galatia, they were prevented by the Holy Spirit from speaking the Word in Asia.
verses.textLa: Transeuntes autem Phrygiam, et Galatiæ regionem, vetati sunt a Spiritu Sancto loqui verbum Dei in Asia.

verses.textEn: But when they had arrived in Mysia, they attempted to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus would not permit them.
verses.textLa: Cum venissent autem in Mysiam, tentabant ire in Bithyniam: et non permisit eos Spiritus Iesu.

verses.textEn: Then, when they had crossed through Mysia, they descended to Troas.
verses.textLa: Cum autem pertransissent Mysiam, descendeunt Troadem:

verses.textEn: And a vision in the night was revealed to Paul of a certain man of Macedonia, standing and pleading with him, and saying: “Cross into Macedonia and help us!”
verses.textLa: et visio per noctem Paulo ostensa est: Vir Macedo quidam erat stans, et deprecans eum, et dicens: Transiens in Macedoniam, adiuva nos.

verses.textEn: Then, after he saw the vision, immediately we sought to set out for Macedonia, having been assured that God had called us to evangelize to them.
verses.textLa: Ut autem visum vidit, statim quæsivimus proficisci in Macedoniam, certi facti quod vocasset nos Deus evangelizare eis.

verses.textEn: And sailing from Troas, taking a direct path, we arrived at Samothrace, and on the following day, at Neapolis,
verses.textLa: Navigantes autem a Troade, recto cursu venimus Samothraciam, et sequenti die Neapolim:

verses.textEn: and from there to Philippi, which is the preeminent city in the area of Macedonia, a colony. Now we were in this city some days, conferring together.
verses.textLa: et inde Philippos, quæ est prima partis Macedoniæ civitas, colonia. Eramus autem in hac urbe diebus aliquot, conferentes.

verses.textEn: Then, on the Sabbath day, we were walking outside the gate, beside a river, where there seemed to be a prayer gathering. And sitting down, we were speaking with the women who had assembled.
verses.textLa: Die autem Sabbatorum egressi sumus foras portam iuxta flumen, ubi videbatur oratio esse: et sedentes loquebamur mulieribus, quæ convenerant.
verses.notes: It was a Jewish custom, and apparently a custom of some early Christians, to go for a prayerful or meditative walk on the Sabbath.

verses.textEn: And a certain woman, named Lydia, a seller of purple in the city of Thyatira, a worshiper of God, listened. And the Lord opened her heart to be receptive to what Paul was saying.
verses.textLa: Et quædam mulier nomine Lydia, purpuraria civitatis Thyatirenorum, colens Deum, audivit: cuius Dominus aperuit cor intendere his, quæ dicebantur a Paulo.

verses.textEn: And when she had been baptized, with her household, she pleaded with us, saying: “If you have judged me to be faithful to the Lord, enter into my house and lodge there.” And she convinced us.
verses.textLa: Cum autem baptizata esset, et domus eius, deprecata est dicens: Si iudicastis me fidelem Domino esse, introite in domum meam, et manete. Et coegit nos.

verses.textEn: Then it happened that, as we were going out to prayer, a certain girl, having a spirit of divination, met with us. She was a source of great profit to her masters, through her divining.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem euntibus nobis ad orationem, puellam quamdam habentem spiritum pythonem obviare nobis, quæ quæstum magnum præstabat dominis suis divinando.
verses.notes: This girl is said to have the spirit of a python because the python in Greek mythology was associated with divination.

verses.textEn: This girl, following Paul and us, was crying out, saying: “These men are servants of the Most High God! They are announcing to you the way of salvation!”
verses.textLa: Hæc subsecuta Paulum, et nos, clamabat dicens: Isti homines servi Dei excelsi sunt, qui annunciant vobis viam salutis.

verses.textEn: Now she behaved in this way for many days. But Paul, being grieved, turned and said to the spirit, “I command you, in the name of Jesus Christ, to go out from her.” And it went away in that same hour.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem faciebat multis diebus. Dolens autem Paulus, et conversus, spiritui dixit: Præcipio tibi in nomine Iesu Christi exire ab ea. Et exiit eadem hora.

verses.textEn: But her masters, seeing that the hope of their profit went away, apprehended Paul and Silas, and they brought them to the rulers at the courthouse.
verses.textLa: Videntes autem domini eius quia exivit spes quæstus eorum, apprehendentes Paulum, et Silam perduxerunt in forum ad principes:
verses.notes: The word ‘forum’ often refers to a marketplace, but in this context it refers to a place for judgment and justice, such as a court house.

verses.textEn: And presenting them to the magistrates, they said: “These men are disturbing our city, since they are Jews.
verses.textLa: et offerentes eos magistratibus, dixerunt: Hi homines conturbant civitatem nostram, cum sint Iudæi:

verses.textEn: And they are announcing a way which is not lawful for us to accept or to observe, since we are Romans.”
verses.textLa: et annunciant morem, quem non licet nobis suscipere, neque facere, cum simus Romani.

verses.textEn: And the people rushed together against them. And the magistrates, tearing their tunics, ordered them to be beaten with staffs.
verses.textLa: Et cucurrit plebs adversus eos: et magistratus, scissis tunicis eorum, iusserunt eos virgis cædi.

verses.textEn: And when they had inflicted many scourges on them, they cast them into prison, instructing the guard to watch them diligently.
verses.textLa: Et cum multas plagas eis imposuissent, miserunt eos in carcerem, præcipientes custodi ut diligenter custodiret eos.

verses.textEn: And since he had received this kind of order, he cast them into the interior prison cell, and he restricted their feet with stocks.
verses.textLa: Qui cum tale præceptum accepisset, misit eos in interiorem carcerem, et pedes eorum strinxit ligno.

verses.textEn: Then, in the middle of the night, Paul and Silas were praying and praising God. And those who were also in custody were listening to them.
verses.textLa: Media autem nocte Paulus, et Silas orantes, laudabant Deum: et audiebant eos, qui in custodia erant.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, there was a sudden earthquake, so great that the foundations of the prison were moved. And immediately all the doors were opened, and the bindings of everyone were released.
verses.textLa: Subito vero terræmotus factus est magnus, ita ut moverentur fundamenta carceris. Et statim aperta sunt omnia ostia: et universorum vincula soluta sunt.

verses.textEn: Then the prison guard, having been jarred awake, and seeing the doors of the prison open, drew his sword and intended to kill himself, supposing that the prisoners had fled.
verses.textLa: Expergefactus autem custos carceris, et videns ianuas apertas carceris, evaginato gladio volebat se interficere, æstimans fugisse vinctos.

verses.textEn: But Paul cried out with a loud voice, saying: “Do no harm to yourself, for we are all here!”
verses.textLa: Clamavit autem Paulus voce magna, dicens: Nihil tibi mali feceris: universi enim hic sumus.

verses.textEn: Then calling for a light, he entered. And trembling, he fell before the feet of Paul and Silas.
verses.textLa: Petitoque lumine, introgressus est: et tremefactus procidit Paulo et Silæ ad pedes:

verses.textEn: And bringing them outside, he said, “Sirs, what must I do, so that I may be saved?”
verses.textLa: et producens eos foras, ait: domini, quid me oportet facere, ut salvus fiam?

verses.textEn: So they said, “Believe in the Lord Jesus, and then you will be saved, with your household.”
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt: Crede in Dominum Iesum: et salvus eris tu, et domus tua.

verses.textEn: And they spoke the Word of the Lord to him, along with all those who were in his house.
verses.textLa: Et locuti sunt ei verbum Domini cum omnibus, qui erant in domo eius.

verses.textEn: And he, taking them in the same hour of the night, washed their scourges. And he was baptized, and next his entire household.
verses.textLa: Et tollens eos in illa hora noctis, lavit plagas eorum: et baptizatus est ipse, et omnis domus eius continuo.

verses.textEn: And when he had brought them into his own house, he set a table for them. And he was joyous, with his entire household, believing in God.
verses.textLa: Cumque perduxisset eos in domum suam, apposuit eis mensam, et lætatus est cum omni domo sua credens Deo.

verses.textEn: And when daylight had arrived, the magistrates sent the attendants, saying, “Release those men.”
verses.textLa: Et cum dies factus esset, miserunt magistratus lictores, dicentes: Dimitte homines illos.

verses.textEn: But the prison guard reported these words to Paul: “The magistrates have sent to have you released. Now therefore, depart. Go in peace.”
verses.textLa: Nunciavit autem custos carceris verba hæc Paulo: Quia miserunt magistratus ut dimittamini, nunc igitur exeuntes, ite in pace.

verses.textEn: But Paul said to them: “They have beaten us publicly, though we were not condemned. They have cast men who are Romans into prison. And now they would drive us away secretly? Not so. Instead, let them come forward,
verses.textLa: Paulus autem dixit eis: Cæsos nos publice, indemnatos, homines Romanos miserunt in carcerem, et nunc occulte nos eiiciunt? Non ita: sed veniant,

verses.textEn: and let us drive them away.” Then the attendants reported these words to the magistrates. And upon hearing that they were Romans, they were afraid.
verses.textLa: et ipsi nos eiiciant. Nunciaverunt autem magistratibus lictores verba hæc. Timueruntque audito quod Romani essent:

verses.textEn: And arriving, they pleaded with them, and leading them out, they begged them to depart from the city.
verses.textLa: et venientes deprecati sunt eos, et educentes rogabant ut egrederentur de urbe.

verses.textEn: And they went away from the prison and entered into the house of Lydia. And having seen the brothers, they consoled them, and then they set out.
verses.textLa: Exeuntes autem de carcere, introierunt ad Lydiam: et visis fratribus consolati sunt eos, et profecti sunt.

verses.textEn: Now when they had walked through Amphipolis and Apollonia, they arrived at Thessalonica, where there was a synagogue of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Cum autem perambulassent Amphipolim, et Apolloniam, venerunt Thessalonicam, ubi erat synagoga Iudæorum.

verses.textEn: Then Paul, according to custom, entered to them. And for three Sabbaths he disputed with them about the Scriptures,
verses.textLa: Secundum consuetudinem autem Paulus introivit ad eos, et per sabbata tria disserebat eis de Scripturis,

verses.textEn: interpreting and concluding that it was necessary for the Christ to suffer and to rise again from the dead, and that “this is the Jesus Christ, whom I am announcing to you.”
verses.textLa: adaperiens et insinuans quia Christum oportuit pati, et resurgere a mortuis: et quia hic est Iesus Christus, quem ego annuncio vobis.

verses.textEn: And some of them believed and were joined to Paul and Silas, and a great number of these were from the worshipers and the Gentiles, and not a few were noble women.
verses.textLa: Et quidam ex eis crediderunt, et adiuncti sunt Paulo, et Silæ, et de colentibus, Gentilibusque multitudo magna, et mulieres nobiles non paucæ.
verses.notes: The ‘worshipers’ here are probably the pagan worshipers among the Gentiles, and the ‘Gentiles’ are therefore those non-Jews who did not follow even a pagan religion.

verses.textEn: But the Jews, being jealous, and joining with certain evildoers among the common men, caused a disturbance, and they stirred up the city. And taking up a position near the house of Jason, they sought to lead them out to the people.
verses.textLa: Zelantes autem Iudæi, assumentesque de vulgo viros quosdam malos, et turba facta, concitaverunt civitatem: et assistentes domui Iasonis quærebant eos producere in populum.

verses.textEn: And when they had not found them, they dragged Jason and certain brothers to the rulers of the city, crying out: “For these are the ones who have stirred up the city. And they came here,
verses.textLa: Et cum non invenissent eos, trahebant Iasonem, et quosdam fratres ad principes civitatis, clamantes: Quoniam hi, qui urbem concitant, et huc venerunt,

verses.textEn: and Jason has received them. And all these men act contrary to the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus.”
verses.textLa: quos suscepit Iason, et hi omnes contra decreta Cæsaris faciunt, regem alium dicentes esse, Iesum.

verses.textEn: And they incited the people. And the rulers of the city, upon hearing these things,
verses.textLa: Concitaverunt autem plebem: et principes civitatis audientes hæc,

verses.textEn: and having received an explanation from Jason and the others, released them.
verses.textLa: et accepta satisfactione a Iasone, et a ceteris, dimiserunt eos.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the brothers promptly sent Paul and Silas away by night to Beroea. And when they had arrived, they entered the synagogue of the Jews.
verses.textLa: Fratres vero confestim per noctem dimiserunt Paulum, et Silam in Berœam. Qui cum venissent, in synagogam Iudæorum introierunt.

verses.textEn: But these were more noble than those who were at Thessalonica. They received the Word with all enthusiasm, daily examining the Scriptures to see if these things were so.
verses.textLa: Hi autem erant nobiliores eorum, qui sunt Thessalonicæ, qui susceperunt verbum cum omni aviditate, quotidie scrutantes Scripturas, si hæc ita se haberent.

verses.textEn: And indeed, many believed among them, as well as not a few among the honorable Gentile men and women.
verses.textLa: Et multi quidem crediderunt ex eis, et mulierum Gentilium honestarum, et viri non pauci.

verses.textEn: Then, when the Jews of Thessalonica had realized that the Word of God was also preached by Paul at Beroea, they went there also, stirring up and disturbing the multitude.
verses.textLa: Cum autem cognovissent in Thessalonica Iudæi, quia et Berœæ prædicatum est a Paulo verbum Dei, venerunt et illuc commoventes, et turbantes multitudinem.

verses.textEn: And then the brothers quickly sent Paul away, so that he might travel by sea. But Silas and Timothy remained there.
verses.textLa: Statimque tunc Paulum dimiserunt fratres, ut iret usque ad mare: Silas autem, et Timotheus remanserunt ibi.

verses.textEn: Then those who were leading Paul brought him as far as Athens. And having received an order from him to Silas and Timothy, that they should come to him quickly, they set out.
verses.textLa: Qui autem deducebant Paulum, perduxerunt eum usque Athenas, et accepto mandato ab eo ad Silam, et Timotheum ut quam celeriter venirent ad illum, profecti sunt.

verses.textEn: Now while Paul waited for them at Athens, his spirit was stirred up within him, seeing the city given over to idolatry.
verses.textLa: Paulus autem cum Athenis eos exspectaret, incitabatur spiritus eius in ipso, videns idololatriæ deditam civitatem.

verses.textEn: And so, he was disputing with the Jews in the synagogue, and with the worshipers, and in public places, throughout each day, with whomever was there.
verses.textLa: Disputabat igitur in synagoga cum Iudæis, et colentibus, et in foro, per omnes dies ad eos, qui aderant.

verses.textEn: Now certain Epicurean and Stoic philosophers were arguing with him. And some were saying, “What does this sower of the Word want to say?” Yet others were saying, “He seems to be an announcer for new demons.” For he was announcing to them Jesus and the Resurrection.
verses.textLa: Quidam autem Epicurei, et Stoici philosophi disserebant cum eo, et quidam dicebant: Quid vult seminiverbius hic, dicere? Alii vero: Novorum dæmoniorum videtur annunciator esse: quia Iesum, et resurrectionem annunciabat eis.

verses.textEn: And apprehending him, they brought him to the Areopagus, saying: “Are we able to know what this new doctrine is, about which you speak?
verses.textLa: Et apprehensum eum ad Areopagum duxerunt, dicentes: Possumus scire quæ est hæc nova, quæ a te dicitur, doctrina?

verses.textEn: For you bring certain new ideas to our ears. And so we would like to know what these things mean.”
verses.textLa: Nova enim quædam infers auribus nostris: Volumus ergo scire quidnam velint hæc esse.

verses.textEn: (Now all the Athenians, and arriving visitors, were occupying themselves with nothing other than speaking or hearing various new ideas.)
verses.textLa: (Athenienses autem omnes, et advenæ hospites, ad nihil aliud vacabant nisi aut dicere, aut audire aliquid novi.)

verses.textEn: But Paul, standing in the middle of the Areopagus, said: “Men of Athens, I perceive that in all things you are rather superstitious.
verses.textLa: Stans autem Paulus in medio Areopagi, ait: Viri Athenienses per omnia quasi superstitiosiores vos video.

verses.textEn: For as I was passing by and noticing your idols, I also found an altar, on which was written: TO THE UNKNOWN GOD. Therefore, what you worship in ignorance, this is what I am preaching to you:
verses.textLa: Præteriens enim, et videns simulacra vestra, inveni et aram, in qua scriptum erat: IGNOTO DEO. Quod ergo ignorantes colitis, hoc ego annuncio vobis.

verses.textEn: the God who made the world and all that is in it, the One who is the Lord of heaven and earth, who does not live in temples made with hands.
verses.textLa: Deus, qui fecit mundum, et omnia quæ in eo sunt, hic cæli et terræ cum sit Dominus, non in manufactis templis habitat,

verses.textEn: Neither is he served by the hands of men, as if in need of anything, since it is he who gives to all things life and breath and all else.
verses.textLa: nec manibus humanis colitur indigens aliquo, cum ipse det omnibus vitam, et inspirationem, et omnia:

verses.textEn: And he has made, out of one, every family of man: to live upon the face of the entire earth, determining the appointed seasons and the limits of their habitation,
verses.textLa: fecitque ex uno omne genus hominum inhabitare super universam faciem terræ, definiens statuta tempora, et terminos habitationis eorum,
verses.notes: The one out of whom God made every family of mankind is Adam.

verses.textEn: so as to seek God, if perhaps they may consider him or find him, though he is not far from each one of us.
verses.textLa: quærere Deum si forte attrectent eum, aut inveniant, quam vis non longe sit ab unoquoque nostrum.

verses.textEn: ‘For in him we live, and move, and exist.’ Just as some of your own poets have said. ‘For we are also of his family.’
verses.textLa: In ipso enim vivimus, et movemur, et sumus: sicut et quidam vestrorum Poetarum dixerunt: Ipsius enim et genus sumus.

verses.textEn: Therefore, since we are of the family of God, we must not consider gold or silver or precious stones, or the engravings of art and of the imagination of man, to be a representation of what is Divine.
verses.textLa: Genus ergo cum simus Dei, non debemus æstimare auro, aut argento, aut lapidi, sculpturæ artis, et cogitationis hominis, Divinum esse simile.

verses.textEn: And indeed, God, having looked down to see the ignorance of these times, has now announced to men that everyone everywhere should do penance.
verses.textLa: Et tempora quidem huius ignorantiæ despiciens Deus, nunc annunciat hominibus ut omnes ubique pœnitentiam agant,

verses.textEn: For he has appointed a day on which he will judge the world in equity, through the man whom he has appointed, offering faith to all, by raising him from the dead.”
verses.textLa: eo quod statuit diem, in quo iudicaturus est orbem in æquitate, in viro, in quo statuit, fidem præbens omnibus, suscitans eum a mortuis.

verses.textEn: And when they had heard about the Resurrection of the dead, indeed, some were derisive, while others said, “We will listen to you about this again.”
verses.textLa: Cum audissent autem resurrectionem mortuorum, quidam quidem irridebant, quidam vero dixerunt: Audiemus te de hoc iterum.

verses.textEn: So Paul departed from their midst.
verses.textLa: Sic Paulus exivit de medio eorum.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, certain men, adhering to him, did believe. Among these were also Dionysius the Areopagite, and a woman named Damaris, and others with them.
verses.textLa: Quidam vero viri adhærentes ei, crediderunt: in quibus et Dionysius Areopagita, et mulier nomine Damaris, et alii cum eis.

verses.textEn: After these things, having departed from Athens, he arrived at Corinth.
verses.textLa: Post hæc egressus ab Athenis, venit Corinthum:

verses.textEn: And upon finding a certain Jew named Aquila, born in Pontus, who had recently arrived from Italy with Priscilla his wife, (because Claudius had ordered all Jews to depart from Rome,) he met with them.
verses.textLa: et inveniens quemdam Iudæum nomine Aquilam, Ponticum genere, qui nuper venerat ab Italia, et Priscillam uxorem eius, (eo quod præcepisset Claudius discedere omnes Iudæos a Roma) accessit ad eos.

verses.textEn: And because he was of the same trade, he lodged with them and was working. (Now they were tentmakers by trade.)
verses.textLa: Et quia eiusdem erat artis, manebat apud eos, et operabatur: (erant autem scenofactoriæ artis.)

verses.textEn: And he was arguing in the synagogue on every Sabbath, introducing the name of the Lord Jesus. And he was persuading Jews and Greeks.
verses.textLa: Et disputabat in synagoga per omne Sabbatum, interponens nomen Domini Iesu, suadebatque Iudæis, et Græcis.

verses.textEn: And when Silas and Timothy had arrived from Macedonia, Paul stood firm in the Word, testifying to the Jews that Jesus is the Christ.
verses.textLa: Cum venissent autem de Macedonia Silas et Timotheus, instabat verbo Paulus, testificans Iudæis esse Christum Iesum.

verses.textEn: But since they were contradicting him and blaspheming, he shook out his garments and said to them: “Your blood is on your own heads. I am clean. From now on, I will go to the Gentiles.”
verses.textLa: Contradicentibus autem eis, et blasphemantibus, excutiens vestimenta sua, dixit ad eos: Sanguis vester super caput vestrum: mundus ego, ex hoc ad Gentes vadam.

verses.textEn: And moving from that place, he entered into the house of a certain man, named Titus the Just, a worshiper of God, whose house was adjoined to the synagogue.
verses.textLa: Et migrans inde, intravit in domum cuiusdam, nomine Titi Iusti, colentis Deum, cuius domus erat coniuncta synagogæ.

verses.textEn: Now Crispus, a leader of the synagogue, believed in the Lord, with his entire house. And many of the Corinthians, upon hearing, believed and were baptized.
verses.textLa: Crispus autem archisynagogus credidit Domino cum omni domo sua: et multi Corinthiorum audientes credebant, et baptizabantur.

verses.textEn: Then the Lord said to Paul, through a vision in the night: “Do not be afraid. Instead, speak out and do not be silent.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Dominus nocte per visionem Paulo: Noli timere, sed loquere, et ne taceas:

verses.textEn: For I am with you. And no one will take hold of you, so as to do you harm. For many of the people in this city are with me.”
verses.textLa: propter quod ego sum tecum: et nemo apponetur tibi ut noceat te: quoniam populus est mihi multus in hac civitate.

verses.textEn: Then he settled there for a year and six months, teaching the Word of God among them.
verses.textLa: Sedit autem ibi annum et sex menses, docens apud eos verbum Dei.

verses.textEn: But when Gallio was proconsul of Achaia, the Jews rose up with one accord against Paul. And they brought him to the tribunal,
verses.textLa: Gallione autem proconsule Achaiæ, insurrexerunt uno animo Iudæi in Paulum, et adduxerunt eum ad tribunal,

verses.textEn: saying, “He persuades men to worship God contrary to the law.”
verses.textLa: dicentes: Quia contra legem hic persuadet hominibus colere Deum.

verses.textEn: Then, when Paul was beginning to open his mouth, Gallio said to the Jews: “If this were some matter of injustice, or a wicked deed, O noble Jews, I would support you, as is proper.
verses.textLa: Incipiente autem Paulo aperire os, dixit Gallio ad Iudæos: Si quidem esset iniquum aliquid, aut facinus pessimum o viri Iudæi, recte vos sustinerem.

verses.textEn: Yet if truly these are questions about a word and names and your law, you should see to it yourselves. I will not be the judge of such things.”
verses.textLa: Si vero quæstiones sunt de verbo, et nominibus, et lege vestra, vos ipsi videritis: Iudex ego horum nolo esse.

verses.textEn: And he ordered them from the tribunal.
verses.textLa: Et minavit eos a tribunali.

verses.textEn: But they, apprehending Sosthenes, a leader of the synagogue, beat him in front of the tribunal. And Gallio showed no concern for these things.
verses.textLa: Apprehendentes autem omnes Sosthenem principem synagogæ, percutiebant eum ante tribunal: et nihil eorum Gallioni curæ erat.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Paul, after he had remained for many more days, having said goodbye to the brothers, sailed into Syria, and with him were Priscilla and Aquila. Now he had shaved his head in Cenchreae, for he had made a vow.
verses.textLa: Paulus vero cum adhuc sustinuisset dies multos, fratribus valefaciens, navigavit in Syriam, (et cum eo Priscilla, et Aquila) qui sibi totonderat in Cenchris caput: habebat enim votum.

verses.textEn: And he arrived at Ephesus, and he left them behind there. Yet truly, he himself, entering into the synagogue, was disputing with the Jews.
verses.textLa: Devenitque Ephesum, et illos ibi reliquit. Ipse vero ingressus synagogam, disputabat cum Iudæis.

verses.textEn: Then, although they were asking him to remain for a longer time, he would not agree.
verses.textLa: Rogantibus autem eis ut ampliori tempore maneret, non consensit,

verses.textEn: Instead, saying goodbye and telling them, “I will return to you again, God willing,” he set out from Ephesus.
verses.textLa: sed valefaciens, et dicens, Iterum revertar ad vos Deo volente, profectus est ab Epheso.

verses.textEn: And after going down to Caesarea, he went up to Jerusalem, and he greeted the Church there, and then he descended to Antioch.
verses.textLa: Et descendens Cæsaream, ascendit, et salutavit Ecclesiam, et descendit Antiochiam.

verses.textEn: And having spent some length of time there, he set out, and he walked in order through the region of Galatia and Phrygia, strengthening all the disciples.
verses.textLa: Et facto ibi aliquanto tempore, profectus est, perambulans ex ordine Galaticam regionem, et Phrygiam, confirmans omnes discipulos.

verses.textEn: Now a certain Jew named Apollo, born at Alexandria, an eloquent man who was powerful with the Scriptures, arrived at Ephesus.
verses.textLa: Iudæus autem quidam, Apollo nomine, Alexandrinus genere, vir eloquens, devenit Ephesum, potens in scripturis.

verses.textEn: He was learned in the Way of the Lord. And being fervent in spirit, he was speaking and teaching the things that are of Jesus, but knowing only the baptism of John.
verses.textLa: Hic erat edoctus viam Domini: et fervens spiritu loquebatur, et docebat diligenter ea, quæ sunt Iesu, sciens tantum baptisma Ioannis.

verses.textEn: And so, he began to act faithfully in the synagogue. And when Priscilla and Aquila had heard him, they took him aside and expounded the Way of the Lord to him more thoroughly.
verses.textLa: Hic ergo cœpit fiducialiter agere in synagoga. Quem cum audissent Priscilla et Aquila, assumpserunt eum, et diligentius exposuerunt ei viam Domini.

verses.textEn: Then, since he wanted to go to Achaia, the brothers wrote an exhortation to the disciples, so that they might accept him. And when he had arrived, he held many discussions with those who had believed.
verses.textLa: Cum autem vellet ire Achaiam, exhortati fratres, scripserunt discipulis ut susciperent eum. Qui cum venisset, contulit multum his, qui crediderant.

verses.textEn: For he was vehemently and publicly reproving the Jews, by revealing through the Scriptures that Jesus is the Christ.
verses.textLa: Vehementer enim Iudæos revincebat publice, ostendens per Scripturas, esse Christum Iesum.

verses.textEn: Now it happened that, while Apollo was at Corinth, Paul, after he had journeyed through the upper regions, arrived at Ephesus. And he met with certain disciples.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, cum Apollo esset Corinthi, ut Paulus peragratis superioribus partibus veniret Ephesum, et inveniret quosdam Discipulos:

verses.textEn: And he said to them, “After believing, have you received the Holy Spirit?” But they said to him, “We have not even heard that there is a Holy Spirit.”
verses.textLa: dixitque ad eos: Si Spiritum Sanctum accepistis credentes? At illi dixerunt ad eum: Sed neque si Spiritus Sanctus est, audivimus.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, he said, “Then with what have you been baptized?” And they said, “With the baptism of John.”
verses.textLa: Ille vero ait: In quo ergo baptizati estis? Qui dixerunt: In Ioannis baptismate.

verses.textEn: Then Paul said: “John baptized the people with the baptism of repentance, saying that they should believe in the One who is to come after him, that is, in Jesus.”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Paulus: Ioannes baptizavit baptismo pœnitentiæ populum, dicens: In eum, qui venturus esset post ipsum, ut crederent, hoc est, in Iesum.

verses.textEn: Upon hearing these things, they were baptized in the name of the Lord Jesus.
verses.textLa: His auditis, baptizati sunt in nomine Domini Iesu.
verses.notes: Although the Church currently requires the Trinitarian formula for a valid Baptism, it is apparent from Scripture that some of the earliest valid Baptisms used only the name of Jesus.

verses.textEn: And when Paul had imposed his hands on them, the Holy Spirit came over them. And they were speaking in tongues and prophesying.
verses.textLa: Et cum imposuisset illis manus Paulus, venit Spiritus Sanctus super eos, et loquebantur linguis, et prophetabant.
verses.notes: After being baptized, they were then given the Sacrament of Confirmation.

verses.textEn: Now the men were about twelve in all.
verses.textLa: Erant autem omnes viri fere duodecim.

verses.textEn: Then, upon entering the synagogue, he was speaking faithfully for three months, disputing and persuading them about the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Introgressus autem synagogam, cum fiducia loquebatur per tres menses, disputans, et suadens de regno Dei.

verses.textEn: But when certain ones became hardened and would not believe, cursing the Way of the Lord in the presence of the multitude, Paul, withdrawing from them, separated the disciples, disputing daily in a certain school of Tyrannus.
verses.textLa: Cum autem quidam indurarentur, et non crederent, maledicentes viam Domini coram multitudine, discedens ab eis, segregavit discipulos, quotidie disputans in schola Tyranni cuiusdam.

verses.textEn: Now this was done throughout two years, so that all who were living in Asia listened to the Word of the Lord, both Jews and Gentiles.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem factum est per biennium, ita ut omnes, qui habitabant in Asia, audirent verbum Domini, Iudæi atque Gentiles.

verses.textEn: And God was accomplishing powerful and uncommon miracles by the hand of Paul,
verses.textLa: Virtutesque non quaslibet faciebat Deus per manum Pauli:

verses.textEn: so much so that even when small cloths and wrappings were brought from his body to the sick, the illnesses withdrew from them and the wicked spirits departed.
verses.textLa: ita ut etiam super languidos deferrentur a corpore eius sudaria, et semicinctia, et recedebant ab eis languores, et spiritus nequam egrediebantur.

verses.textEn: Then, even some of the traveling Jewish exorcists had attempted to invoke the name of the Lord Jesus over those who had evil spirits, saying, “I bind you by oath through Jesus, whom Paul preaches.”
verses.textLa: Tentaverunt autem quidam et de circumeuntibus Iudæis exorcistis, invocare super eos, qui habebant spiritus malos, nomen Domini Iesu, dicentes: Adiuro vos per Iesum, quem Paulus prædicat.

verses.textEn: And there were certain Jews, the seven sons of Sceva, leaders among the priests, who were acting in this way.
verses.textLa: Erant autem quidam Iudæi Scevæ principis sacerdotum septem filii, qui hoc faciebant.

verses.textEn: But a wicked spirit responded by saying to them: “Jesus I know, and Paul I know. But who are you?”
verses.textLa: Respondens autem spiritus nequam dixit eis: Iesum novi, et Paulum scio: vos autem qui estis?

verses.textEn: And the man, in whom there was a wicked spirit, leaping at them and getting the better of them both, prevailed against them, so that they fled from that house, naked and wounded.
verses.textLa: Et insiliens in eos homo, in quo erat dæmonium pessimum, et dominatus amborum, invaluit contra eos, ita ut nudi, et vulnerati effugerent de domo illa.

verses.textEn: And so, this became known to all the Jews and Gentiles who were living at Ephesus. And a fear fell over them all. And the name of the Lord Jesus was magnified.
verses.textLa: Hoc autem notum factum est omnibus Iudæis, atque Gentilibus, qui habitabant Ephesi: et cecidit timor super omnes illos, et magnificabatur nomen Domini Iesu.

verses.textEn: And many believers were arriving, confessing, and announcing their deeds.
verses.textLa: Multique credentium veniebant, confitentes, et annunciantes actus suos.

verses.textEn: Then many of those who had followed odd sects brought together their books, and they burned them in the sight of all. And after determining the value of these, they found the price to be fifty thousand denarii.
verses.textLa: Multi autem ex eis, qui fuerant curiosa sectati, contulerunt libros, et combusserunt coram omnibus: et computatis pretiis illorum, invenerunt pecuniam denariorum quinquaginta millium.
verses.notes: A denarius was a decent day’s wage. Perhaps the equivalent today, very approximately, of about 80 dollars a day. Thus the value of those books (scrolls) was equivalent to about 4 million dollars.

verses.textEn: In this way, the Word of God was increasing strongly and was being confirmed.
verses.textLa: Ita fortiter crescebat verbum Dei, et confirmabatur.

verses.textEn: Then, when these things were completed, Paul decided in the Spirit, after crossing through Macedonia and Achaia, to go to Jerusalem, saying, “Then, after I have been there, it is necessary for me to see Rome also.”
verses.textLa: His autem expletis, proposuit Paulus in Spiritu, transita Macedonia et Achaia ire Ierosolymam, dicens: quoniam postquam fuero ibi, oportet me et Romam videre.

verses.textEn: But sending two of those who were ministering to him, Timothy and Erastus, into Macedonia, he himself remained for a time in Asia.
verses.textLa: Mittens autem in Macedoniam duos ex ministrantibus sibi, Timotheum, et Erastum, ipse remansit ad tempus in Asia.

verses.textEn: Now at that time, there occurred no small disturbance concerning the Way of the Lord.
verses.textLa: Facta est autem illo tempore turbatio non minima de via Domini.

verses.textEn: For a certain man named Demetrius, a silversmith making silver shrines for Diana, was providing no small profit to craftsmen.
verses.textLa: Demetrius enim quidam nomine, argentarius, faciens ædes argenteas Dianæ, præstabat artificibus non modicum quæstum:

verses.textEn: And calling them together, with those who were employed in the same way, he said: “Men, you know that our income is from this craft.
verses.textLa: quos convocans, et eos, qui huiusmodi erant opifices, dixit: Viri, scitis quia de hoc artificio est nobis acquisitio:

verses.textEn: And you are seeing and hearing that this man Paul, by persuasion, has turned away a great multitude, not only from Ephesus, but from nearly all of Asia, saying, ‘These things are not gods which have been made by hands.’
verses.textLa: et videtis, et auditis quia non solum Ephesi, sed pene totius Asiæ, Paulus hic suadens avertit multam turbam, dicens: Quoniam non sunt dii, qui manibus fiunt.

verses.textEn: Thus, not only is this, our occupation, in danger of being brought into repudiation, but also the temple of the great Diana will be reputed as nothing! Then even her majesty, whom all of Asia and the world worships, will begin to be destroyed.”
verses.textLa: Non solum autem hæc periclitabitur nobis pars in redargutionem venire, sed et magnæ Dianæ templum in nihilum reputabitur, sed et destrui incipiet maiestas eius, quam tota Asia, et orbis colit.

verses.textEn: Upon hearing this, they were filled with anger, and they cried out, saying, “Great is Diana of the Ephesians!”
verses.textLa: His auditis, repleti sunt ira, et exclamaverunt dicentes: Magna Diana Ephesiorum.

verses.textEn: And the city was filled with confusion. And having seized Gaius and Aristarchus of Macedonia, companions of Paul, they rushed violently, with one accord, into the amphitheater.
verses.textLa: Et impleta est civitas confusione, et impetum fecerunt uno animo in theatrum, rapto Gaio, et Aristarcho Macedonibus, comitibus Pauli.

verses.textEn: Then, when Paul wanted to enter to the people, the disciples would not permit him.
verses.textLa: Paulo autem volente intrare in populum, non permiserunt discipuli.

verses.textEn: And some of the leaders from Asia, who were his friends, also sent to him, requesting that he not present himself in the amphitheater.
verses.textLa: Quidam autem et de Asiæ principibus, qui erant amici eius, miserunt ad eum rogantes ne se daret in theatrum:

verses.textEn: But others were crying out various things. For the assembly was in confusion, and most did not know the reason they had been called together.
verses.textLa: alii autem aliud clamabant. Erat enim ecclesia confusa: et plures nesciebant qua ex causa convenissent.

verses.textEn: So they dragged Alexander from the crowd, while the Jews were propelling him forward. And Alexander, gesturing with his hand for silence, wanted to give the people an explanation.
verses.textLa: De turba autem detraxerunt Alexandrum, propellentibus eum Iudæis. Alexander autem manu silentio postulato, volebat reddere rationem populo.

verses.textEn: But as soon as they realized him to be a Jew, all with one voice, for about two hours, were crying out, “Great is Diana of the Ephesians!”
verses.textLa: Quem ut cognoverunt Iudæum esse, vox facta una est omnium, quasi per horas duas clamantium: Magna Diana Ephesiorum.

verses.textEn: And when the scribe had calmed the crowds, he said: “Men of Ephesus, now what man is there who does not know that the city of the Ephesians is in the service of the great Diana and of the offspring of Jupiter?
verses.textLa: Et cum sedasset scriba turbas, dixit: Viri Ephesii, quis enim est hominum, qui nesciat Ephesiorum civitatem cultricem esse magnæ Dianæ, Iovisque prolis?

verses.textEn: Therefore, since these things are not able to be contradicted, it is necessary for you to be calm and to do nothing rash.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo his contradici non possit, oportet vos sedatos esse, et nihil temere agere.

verses.textEn: For you have brought forward these men, who are neither sacrilegious nor blasphemers against your goddess.
verses.textLa: Adduxistis enim homines istos, neque sacrilegos, neque blasphemantes deam vestram.

verses.textEn: But if Demetrius and the craftsmen who are with him have a case against anyone, they can convene in the courts, and there are proconsuls. Let them accuse one another.
verses.textLa: Quod si Demetrius, et qui cum eo sunt artifices, habent adversus aliquem causam, conventus forenses aguntur, et proconsules sunt, accusent invicem.

verses.textEn: But if you would inquire about other things, this can be decided in a lawful assembly.
verses.textLa: Si quid autem alterius rei quæritis: in legitima ecclesia poterit absolvi.

verses.textEn: For now we are in peril of being convicted of sedition over today’s events, since there is no one guilty (against whom we are able to provide evidence) in this gathering.” And when he had said this, he dismissed the assembly.
verses.textLa: Nam et periclitamur argui seditionis hodiernæ: cum nullus obnoxius sit (de quo possimus reddere rationem) concursus istius. Et cum hæc dixisset, dimisit ecclesiam.

verses.textEn: Then, after the tumult ceased, Paul, calling the disciples to himself and exhorting them, said farewell. And he set out, so that he might go into Macedonia.
verses.textLa: Postquam autem cessavit tumultus, vocatis Paulus discipulis, et exhortatus eos, valedixit, et profectus est ut iret in Macedoniam.

verses.textEn: And when he had walked through those areas and had exhorted them with many sermons, he went into Greece.
verses.textLa: Cum autem perambulasset partes illas, et exhortatus eos fuisset multo sermone, venit ad Græciam:

verses.textEn: After he had spent three months there, treacheries were planned against him by the Jews, just as he was about to sail into Syria. And having been advised of this, he return through Macedonia.
verses.textLa: ubi cum fecisset menses tres, factæ sunt illi insidiæ a Iudæis navigaturo in Syriam: habuitque consilium ut reverteretur per Macedoniam.

verses.textEn: Now those accompanying him were Sopater, the son of Pyrrhus from Beroea; and also the Thessalonians, Aristarchus and Secundus; and Gaius of Derbe, and Timothy; and also Tychicus and Trophimus from Asia.
verses.textLa: Comitatus est autem eum Sopater Pyrrhi Berœensis, Thessalonicensium vero Aristarchus, et Secundus, et Gaius Derbeus, et Timotheus: Asiani vero Tychicus, et Trophimus.

verses.textEn: These, after they had gone ahead, waited for us at Troas.
verses.textLa: Hi cum præcessissent, sustinuerunt nos Troade:

verses.textEn: Yet truly, we sailed from Philippi, after the days of Unleavened Bread, and in five days we went to them at Troas, where we stayed for seven days.
verses.textLa: nos vero navigavimus post dies Azymorum a Philippis, et venimus ad eos Troadem in diebus quinque, ubi demorati sumus diebus septem.

verses.textEn: Then, on the first Sabbath, when we had assembled together to break bread, Paul discoursed with them, intending to set out the next day. But he prolonged his sermon into the middle of the night.
verses.textLa: Una autem Sabbati cum convenissemus ad frangendum panem, Paulus disputabat cum eis profecturus in crastinum, protraxitque sermonem usque in mediam noctem.

verses.textEn: Now there were plenty of lamps in the upper room, where we were gathered.
verses.textLa: Erant autem lampades copiosæ in cœnaculo, ubi eramus congregati.

verses.textEn: And a certain adolescent named Eutychus, sitting on the window sill, was being weighed down by a heavy drowsiness (for Paul was preaching at length). Then, as he went to sleep, he fell from the third floor room downward. And when he was lifted up, he was dead.
verses.textLa: Sedens autem quidam adolescens nomine Eutychus super fenestram, cum mergeretur somno gravi, disputante diu Paulo, ductus somno cecidit de tertio cœnaculo deorsum, et sublatus est mortuus.

verses.textEn: When Paul had gone down to him, he laid himself over him and, embracing him, said, “Do not worry, for his soul is still within him.”
verses.textLa: Ad quem cum descendisset Paulus, incubuit super eum: et complexus dixit: Nolite turbari, anima enim ipsius in ipso est.

verses.textEn: And so, going up, and breaking bread, and eating, and having spoken well on until daylight, he then set out.
verses.textLa: Ascendens autem, frangensque panem, et gustans, satisque allocutus usque in lucem, sic profectus est.

verses.textEn: Now they had brought the boy in alive, and they were more than a little consoled.
verses.textLa: Adduxerunt autem puerum viventem, et consolati sunt non minime.

verses.textEn: Then we climbed aboard the ship and sailed to Assos, where we were to take in Paul. For so he himself had decided, since he was making the journey by land.
verses.textLa: Nos autem ascendentes navem, navigavimus in Asson, inde suscepturi Paulum: sic enim disposuerat ipse per terram iter facturus.

verses.textEn: And when he had joined us at Assos, we took him in, and we went to Mitylene.
verses.textLa: Cum autem convenisset nos in Asson, assumpto eo, venimus Mitylenen.

verses.textEn: And sailing from there, on the following day, we arrived opposite Chios. And next we landed at Samos. And on the following day we went to Miletus.
verses.textLa: Et inde navigantes, sequenti die venimus contra Chium, et alia applicuimus Samum, et sequenti die venimus Miletum.

verses.textEn: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus, so that he would not be delayed in Asia. For he was hurrying so that, if it were possible for him, he might observe the day of Pentecost at Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Proposuerat enim Paulus transnavigare Ephesum, ne qua mora illi fieret in Asia. Festinabat enim, si possibile sibi esset, ut diem Pentecostes faceret Ierosolymis.

verses.textEn: Then, sending from Miletus to Ephesus, he called those greater by birth in the church.
verses.textLa: A Mileto autem mittens Ephesum, vocavit Maiores natu Ecclesiæ.

verses.textEn: And when they had come to him and were together, he said to them: “You know that from the first day when I entered into Asia, I have been with you, for the entire time, in this manner:
verses.textLa: Qui cum venissent ad eum, et simul essent, dixit eis: Vos scitis a prima die, qua ingressus sum in Asiam, qualiter vobiscum per omne tempus fuerim,

verses.textEn: serving the Lord, with all humility and despite the tears and trials which befell me from the treacheries of the Jews,
verses.textLa: serviens Domino cum omni humilitate, et lacrymis, et tentationibus, quæ mihi acciderunt ex insidiis Iudæorum:

verses.textEn: how I held back nothing that was of value, how well I have preached to you, and that I have taught you publicly and throughout the houses,
verses.textLa: quo modo nihil subtraxerim utilium, quominus annunciarem vobis, et docerem vos publice, et per domos,

verses.textEn: testifying both to Jews and to Gentiles about repentance in God and faith in our Lord Jesus Christ.
verses.textLa: testificans Iudæis, atque Gentilibus in Deum pœnitentiam, et fidem in Dominum nostrum Iesum Christum.

verses.textEn: And now, behold, being obliged in spirit, I am going to Jerusalem, not knowing what will happen to me there,
verses.textLa: Et nunc ecce alligatus ego spiritu, vado in Ierusalem: quæ in ea ventura sint mihi, ignorans:

verses.textEn: except that the Holy Spirit, throughout every city, has cautioned me, saying that chains and tribulations await me at Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: nisi quod Spiritus Sanctus per omnes civitates mihi protestatur, dicens: quoniam vincula, et tribulationes Ierosolymis me manent.

verses.textEn: But I dread none of these things. Neither do I consider my life to be more precious because it is my own, provided that in some way I may complete my own course and that of the ministry of the Word, which I received from the Lord Jesus, to testify to the Gospel of the grace of God.
verses.textLa: Sed nihil horum vereor: nec facio animam meam pretiosiorem quam me, dum modo consummem cursum meum, et ministerium verbi, quod accepi a Domino Iesu, testificari Evangelium gratiæ Dei.

verses.textEn: And now, behold, I know that you will no longer see my face, all of you among whom I have traveled, preaching the kingdom of God.
verses.textLa: Et nunc ecce ego scio quia amplius non videbitis faciem meam vos omnes, per quos transivi prædicans regnum Dei.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I call you as witnesses on this very day: that I am clean from the blood of all.
verses.textLa: Quapropter contestor vos hodierna die, quia mundus sum a sanguine omnium.

verses.textEn: For I have not turned aside in the least from announcing every counsel of God to you.
verses.textLa: Non enim subterfugi, quominus annunciarem omne consilium Dei vobis.

verses.textEn: Take care of yourselves and of the entire flock, over which the Holy Spirit has stationed you as Bishops to rule the Church of God, which he has purchased by his own blood.
verses.textLa: Attendite vobis, et universo gregi, in quo vos Spiritus Sanctus posuit Episcopos regere Ecclesiam Dei, quam acquisivit sanguine suo.

verses.textEn: I know that after my departure ravenous wolves will enter among you, not sparing the flock.
verses.textLa: Ego scio quoniam intrabunt post discessionem meam lupi rapaces in vos, non parcentes gregi.

verses.textEn: And from among yourselves, men will rise up, speaking perverse things in order to entice disciples after them.
verses.textLa: Et ex vobis ipsis exurgent viri loquentes perversa, ut abducant discipulos post se.

verses.textEn: Because of this, be vigilant, retaining in memory that throughout three years I did not cease, night and day, with tears, to admonish each and every one of you.
verses.textLa: Propter quod vigilate memoria retinentes: quoniam per triennium nocte et die non cessavi, cum lacrymis monens unumquemque vestrum.

verses.textEn: And now, I commend you to God and to the Word of his grace. He has the power to build up, and to give an inheritance to all who are sanctified.
verses.textLa: Et nunc commendo vos Deo, et verbo gratiæ ipsius, qui potens est ædificare, et dare hereditatem in sanctificatis omnibus.

verses.textEn: I have coveted neither silver and gold, nor apparel,
verses.textLa: Argentum, et aurum, aut vestem nullius concupivi,

verses.textEn: as you yourselves know. For that which was needed by me and by those who are with me, these hands have provided.
verses.textLa: sicut ipsi scitis: quoniam ad ea, quæ mihi opus erant, et his, qui mecum sunt, ministraverunt manus istæ.

verses.textEn: I have revealed all things to you, because by laboring in this way, it is necessary to support the weak and to remember the words of the Lord Jesus, how he said, ‘It is more blessed to give than to receive.’ ”
verses.textLa: Omnia ostendi vobis, quoniam sic laborantes, oportet suscipere infirmos, ac meminisse verbi Domini Iesu, quoniam ipse dixit: Beatius est magis dare, quam accipere.

verses.textEn: And when he had said these things, kneeling down, he prayed with all of them.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc dixisset, positis genibus suis oravit cum omnibus illis.

verses.textEn: Then a great weeping occurred among them all. And, falling upon the neck of Paul, they kissed him,
verses.textLa: Magnus autem fletus factus est omnium: et procumbentes super collum Pauli, osculabantur eum,

verses.textEn: being grieved most of all over the word which he had said, that they would never see his face again. And they brought him to the ship.
verses.textLa: dolentes maxime in verbo, quod dixerat, quoniam amplius faciem eius non essent visuri. Et deducebant eum ad navem.

verses.textEn: And after these things had happened, having reluctantly parted from them, we sailed a direct course, arriving at Cos, and on following the day at Rhodes, and from there to Patara.
verses.textLa: Cum autem factum esset ut navigaremus abstracti ab eis, recto cursu venimus Coum, et sequenti die Rhodum, et inde Pataram.

verses.textEn: And when we had found a ship sailing across to Phoenicia, climbing aboard, we set sail.
verses.textLa: Et cum invenissemus navem transfretantem in Phœnicen, ascendentes navigavimus.

verses.textEn: Then, after we had caught sight of Cyprus, keeping it to the left, we sailed on to Syria, and we arrived at Tyre. For the ship was going to unload its cargo there.
verses.textLa: Cum apparuissemus autem Cypro, relinquentes eam ad sinistram, navigavimus in Syriam, et venimus Tyrum: ibi enim navis expositura erat onus.

verses.textEn: Then, having found the disciples, we lodged there for seven days. And they were saying to Paul, through the Spirit, that he should not go up to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Inventis autem discipulis, mansimus ibi diebus septem: qui Paulo dicebant per Spiritum ne ascenderet Ierosolymam.

verses.textEn: And when the days were completed, setting out, we went on; and they all accompanied us with their wives and children, until we were outside of the city. And we kneeled down at the shore and prayed.
verses.textLa: Et expletis diebus profecti ibamus, deducentibus nos omnibus cum uxoribus, et filiis usque foras civitatem: et positis genibus in littore, oravimus.

verses.textEn: And when we had said farewell to one another, we climbed aboard the ship. And they returned to their own.
verses.textLa: Et cum valefecissemus invicem, ascendimus navem: illi autem redierunt in sua.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, having completed our journey by boat from Tyre, we descended to Ptolemais. And greeting the brothers, we lodged with them for one day.
verses.textLa: Nos vero navigatione expleta a Tyro descendimus Ptolemaidam: et salutatis fratribus, mansimus die una apud illos.

verses.textEn: Then, after setting out the next day, we arrived at Caesarea. And upon entering into the house of Philip the evangelist, who was one of the seven, we stayed with him.
verses.textLa: Alia autem die profecti, venimus Cæsaream. Et intrantes domum Philippi evangelistæ, qui erat unus de septem, mansimus apud eum.
verses.notes: This Philip was one of the first seven deacons. He was an Evangelist in that he preached the Gospel. He was not one of the four Evangelists who wrote the Gospels.

verses.textEn: Now this man had four daughters, virgins, who were prophesying.
verses.textLa: Huic autem erant quattuor filiæ virgines prophetantes.

verses.textEn: And while we were delayed for some days, a certain prophet from Judea, named Agabus, arrived.
verses.textLa: Et cum moraremur per dies aliquot, supervenit quidam a Iudæa propheta, nomine Agabus.

verses.textEn: And he, when he had come to us, took Paul’s belt, and binding his own feet and hands, he said: “Thus says the Holy Spirit: The man whose belt this is, the Jews will bind in this way at Jerusalem. And they will deliver him into the hands of the Gentiles.”
verses.textLa: Is cum venisset ad nos, tulit zonam Pauli: et alligans sibi pedes, et manus dixit: Hæc dicit Spiritus Sanctus: Virum, cuius est zona hæc, sic alligabunt in Ierusalem Iudæi, et tradent in manus Gentium.

verses.textEn: And when we had heard this, both we and those who were from that place begged him not to go up to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audissemus, rogabamus nos, et qui loci illius erant, ne ascenderet Ierosolymam.

verses.textEn: Then Paul responded by saying: “What do you accomplish by weeping and afflicting my heart? For I am prepared, not only to be bound, but also to die in Jerusalem, for the name of the Lord Jesus.”
verses.textLa: Tunc respondit Paulus, et dixit: Quid facitis flentes, et affligentes cor meum? Ego enim non solum alligari, sed et mori in Ierusalem paratus sum propter nomen Domini Iesu.

verses.textEn: And since we were not able to persuade him, we quieted, saying: “May the will of the Lord be done.”
verses.textLa: Et cum ei suadere non possemus, quievimus, dicentes: Domini voluntas fiat.

verses.textEn: Then, after those days, having made preparations, we ascended to Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Post dies autem istos præparati, ascendebamus in Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: Now some of the disciples from Caesarea also went with us, bringing with them a certain Cypriot named Mnason, a very old disciple, whose guests we would be.
verses.textLa: Venerunt autem et ex discipulis a Cæsarea nobiscum, adducentes secum apud quem hospitaremur Mnasonem quendam Cyprium, antiquum discipulum.

verses.textEn: And when we had arrived at Jerusalem, the brothers received us willingly.
verses.textLa: Et cum venissemus Ierosolymam, libenter exceperunt nos fratres.

verses.textEn: Then, on the following day, Paul entered with us to James. And all the elders were assembled.
verses.textLa: Sequenti autem die introibat Paulus nobiscum ad Iacobum, omnesque collecti sunt seniores.

verses.textEn: And when he had greeted them, he explained each thing that God had accomplished among the Gentiles through his ministry.
verses.textLa: Quos cum salutasset, narrabat per singula, quæ Deus fecisset in Gentibus per ministerium ipsius.

verses.textEn: And they, upon hearing it, magnified God and said to him: “You understand, brother, how many thousands there are among the Jews who have believed, and they are all zealous for the law.
verses.textLa: At illi cum audissent, magnificabant Deum, dixeruntque ei: Vides frater, quot millia sunt in Iudæis, qui crediderunt, et omnes æmulatores sunt legis.

verses.textEn: Now they have heard about you, that you are teaching those Jews who are among the Gentiles to withdraw from Moses, telling them that they should not circumcise their sons, nor act according to custom.
verses.textLa: Audierunt autem de te quia discessionem doceas a Moyse eorum, qui per Gentes sunt, Iudæorum: dicens non debere eos circumcidere filios suos, neque secundum consuetudinem ingredi.

verses.textEn: What is next? The multitude ought to be convened. For they will hear that you have arrived.
verses.textLa: Quid ergo est? Utique oportet convenire multitudinem: audient enim te supervenisse.

verses.textEn: Therefore, do this thing that we ask of you: We have four men, who are under a vow.
verses.textLa: Hoc ergo fac quod tibi dicimus: Sunt nobis viri quattuor, votum habentes super se.

verses.textEn: Take these and sanctify yourself with them, and require them to shave their heads. And then everyone will know that the things that they have heard about you are false, but that you yourself walk in keeping with the law.
verses.textLa: His assumptis, sanctifica te cum illis: et impende in illis ut radant capita: et scient omnes quia quæ de te audierunt, falsa sunt, sed ambulas et ipse custodiens legem.

verses.textEn: But, about those Gentiles who have believed, we have written a judgment that they should keep themselves from what has been immolated to idols, and from blood, and from what has been suffocated, and from fornication.”
verses.textLa: De his autem, qui crediderunt ex Gentibus, nos scripsimus iudicantes ut abstineant se ab idolis, immolato, et sanguine, et suffocato, et fornicatione.

verses.textEn: Then Paul, taking the men on the next day, was purified with them, and he entered the temple, announcing the process of the days of purification, until an oblation would be offered on behalf of each one of them.
verses.textLa: Tunc Paulus, assumptis viris, postera die purificatus cum illis intravit in templum, annuncians expletionem dierum purificationis, donec offerretur pro unoquoque eorum oblatio.

verses.textEn: But when the seven days were reaching completion, those Jews who were from Asia, when they had seen him in the temple, incited all the people, and they laid hands on him, crying out:
verses.textLa: Dum autem septem dies consummarentur, hi, qui de Asia erant, Iudæi, cum vidissent eum in templo, concitaverunt omnem populum, et iniecerunt ei manus, clamantes:

verses.textEn: “Men of Israel, help! This is the man who is teaching, everyone, everywhere, against the people and the law and this place. Furthermore, he has even brought Gentiles into the temple, and he has violated this holy place.”
verses.textLa: Viri Israelitæ, adiuvate: hic est homo, qui adversus populum, et legem, et locum hunc, omnes ubique docens, insuper et Gentiles induxit in templum, et violavit sanctum locum istum.

verses.textEn: (For they had seen Trophimus, an Ephesian, in the city with him, and they supposed that Paul had brought him into the temple.)
verses.textLa: Viderant enim Trophimum Ephesium in civitate cum ipso, quem æstimaverunt quoniam in templum introduxisset Paulus.

verses.textEn: And the entire city was stirred up. And it happened that the people ran together. And apprehending Paul, they dragged him outside of the temple. And immediately the doors were closed.
verses.textLa: Commotaque est civitas tota, et facta est concursio populi. Et apprehendentes Paulum, trahebant eum extra templum: et statim clausæ sunt ianuæ.

verses.textEn: Then, as they were seeking to kill him, it was reported to the tribune of the cohort: “All Jerusalem is in confusion.”
verses.textLa: Quærentibus autem eum occidere, nunciatum est Tribuno cohortis: Quia tota confunditur Ierusalem.

verses.textEn: And so, immediately taking soldiers and centurions, he rushed down to them. And when they had seen the tribune and the soldiers, they ceased to strike Paul.
verses.textLa: Qui statim assumptis militibus, et centurionibus, decurrit ad illos. Qui cum vidissent Tribunum, et milites, cessaverunt percutere Paulum.

verses.textEn: Then the tribune, drawing near, apprehended him and ordered that he be bound with two chains. And he was asking who he was and what he had done.
verses.textLa: Tunc accedens Tribunus apprehendit eum, et iussit eum alligari catenis duabus: et interrogabat quis esset, et quid fecisset.

verses.textEn: Then they were crying out various things within the crowd. And since he could not understand anything clearly because of the noise, he ordered him to be brought into the fortress.
verses.textLa: Alii autem aliud clamabant in turba. Et cum non posset certum cognoscere præ tumultu, iussit duci eum in castra.

verses.textEn: And when he had arrived at the stairs, it happened that he was carried up by the soldiers, because of the threat of violence from the people.
verses.textLa: Et cum venisset ad gradus, contigit ut portaretur a militibus propter vim populi.

verses.textEn: For the multitude of the people were following and crying out, “Take him away!”
verses.textLa: Sequebatur enim multitudo populi, clamans: Tolle eum!

verses.textEn: And as Paul was beginning to be brought into the fortress, he said to the tribune, “Is it permissible for me to say something to you?” And he said, “You know Greek?
verses.textLa: Et cum cœpisset induci in castra Paulus, dicit Tribuno: Si licet mihi loqui aliquid ad te? Qui dixit: Græce nosti?

verses.textEn: So then, are you not that Egyptian who before these days incited a rebellion and led out into the desert four thousand murderous men?”
verses.textLa: Nonne tu es Ægyptius, qui ante hos dies tumultum concitasti, et eduxisti in desertum quattuor millia virorum sicariorum?
verses.notes: It is not so much that the men were each murderers, but more that they were of murderous intention.

verses.textEn: But Paul said to him: “I am a man, indeed a Jew, from Tarsus in Cilicia, a citizen of a well-known city. So I petition you, permit me to speak to the people.”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad eum Paulus: Ego homo sum quidem Iudæus a Tarso Ciliciæ, non ignotæ civitatis municeps. Rogo autem te, permitte mihi loqui ad populum.

verses.textEn: And when he had given him permission, Paul, standing on the stairs, motioned with his hand to the people. And when a great silence occurred, he spoke to them in the Hebrew language, saying:
verses.textLa: Et cum ille permisisset, Paulus stans in gradibus, annuit manu ad plebem, et magno silentio facto, allocutus est lingua Hebræa, dicens:

verses.textEn: “Noble brothers and fathers, listen to the explanation that I now give to you.”
verses.textLa: Viri fratres, et patres, audite quam ad vos nunc reddo rationem.

verses.textEn: And when they heard him speaking to them in the Hebrew language, they offered a greater silence.
verses.textLa: Cum audissent autem quia Hebræa lingua loqueretur ad illos, magis præstiterunt silentium.

verses.textEn: And he said: “I am a Jewish man, born at Tarsus in Cilicia, but raised in this city beside the feet of Gamaliel, taught according to the truth of the law of the fathers, zealous for the law, just as all of you also are to this day.
verses.textLa: Et dicit: Ego sum vir Iudæus, natus in Tarso Ciliciæ, nutritus autem in ista civitate, secus pedes Gamaliel eruditus iuxta veritatem paternæ legis, æmulator legis, sicut et vos omnes estis hodie:

verses.textEn: I persecuted this Way, even unto death, binding and delivering into custody both men and women,
verses.textLa: qui hanc viam persecutus sum usque ad mortem, alligans et tradens in custodias viros ac mulieres,

verses.textEn: just as the high priest and all those greater by birth bear witness to me. Having received letters from them to the brothers, I journeyed to Damascus, so that I might lead them bound from there to Jerusalem, so that they might be punished.
verses.textLa: sicut princeps sacerdotum mihi testimonium reddit, et omnes maiores natu, a quibus et epistolas accipiens ad fratres Damascum pergebam, ut adducerem inde vinctos in Ierusalem ut punirentur.

verses.textEn: But it happened that, as I was traveling and was approaching Damascus at midday, suddenly from heaven a great light shone around me.
verses.textLa: Factum est autem, eunte me, et appropinquante Damasco media die, subito de cælo circumfulsit me lux copiosa:

verses.textEn: And falling to the ground, I heard a voice saying to me, ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?’
verses.textLa: et decidens in terram, audivi vocem dicentem mihi: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris?

verses.textEn: And I responded, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And he said to me, ‘I am Jesus the Nazarene, whom you are persecuting.’
verses.textLa: Ego autem respondi: Quis es Domine? Dixitque ad me: Ego sum Iesus Nazarenus, quem tu persequeris.

verses.textEn: And those who were with me, indeed, saw the light, but they did not hear the voice of him who was speaking with me.
verses.textLa: Et qui mecum erant, lumen quidem viderunt, vocem autem non audierunt eius, qui loquebatur mecum.

verses.textEn: And I said, ‘What should I do, Lord?’ Then the Lord said to me: ‘Rise up, and go to Damascus. And there, you shall be told all that you must do.’
verses.textLa: Et dixi: Quid faciam, Domine? Dominus autem dixit ad me: Surgens vade Damascum: et ibi tibi dicetur de omnibus, quæ te oporteat facere.

verses.textEn: And since I could not see, because of the brightness of that light, I was led by the hand by my companions, and I went to Damascus.
verses.textLa: Et cum non viderem præ claritate luminis illius, ad manum deductus a comitibus, veni Damascum.

verses.textEn: Then a certain Ananias, a man in accord with the law, having the testimony of all the Jews who were living there,
verses.textLa: Ananias autem quidam, vir secundum legem testimonium habens ab omnibus cohabitantibus Iudæis,

verses.textEn: drawing near to me and standing close by, said to me, ‘Brother Saul, see!’ And in that same hour, I looked upon him.
verses.textLa: veniens ad me, et astans dixit mihi: Saule frater respice. Et ego eadem hora respexi in eum.

verses.textEn: But he said: ‘The God of our fathers has preordained you, so that you would come to know his will and would see the Just One, and would hear the voice from his mouth.
verses.textLa: At ille dixit: Deus patrum nostrorum præordinavit te, ut cognosceres voluntatem eius, et videres Iustum, et audires vocem ex ore eius:

verses.textEn: For you shall be his witness to all men about those things which you have seen and heard.
verses.textLa: quia eris testis illius ad omnes homines eorum, quæ vidisti, et audisti.

verses.textEn: And now, why do you delay? Rise up, and be baptized, and wash away your sins, by invoking his name.’
verses.textLa: Et nunc quid moraris? Exurge, et baptizare, et ablue peccata tua invocato nomine ipsius.

verses.textEn: Then it happened that, when I returned to Jerusalem and was praying in the temple, a mental stupor came over me,
verses.textLa: Factum est autem revertenti mihi in Ierusalem, et oranti in templo, fieri me in stupore mentis,

verses.textEn: and I saw him saying to me: ‘Hurry! Depart quickly from Jerusalem! For they will not accept your testimony about me.’
verses.textLa: et videre illum dicentem mihi: Festina, et exi velociter ex Ierusalem: quoniam non recipient testimonium tuum de me.

verses.textEn: And I said: ‘Lord, they know that I am beating and enclosing in prison, throughout every synagogue, those who have believed in you.
verses.textLa: Et ego dixi: Domine ipsi sciunt quia ego eram concludens in carcerem, et cædans per synagogas eos, qui credebant in te:

verses.textEn: And when the blood of your witness Stephen was poured out, I stood nearby and was consenting, and I watched over the garments of those who put him to death.’
verses.textLa: et cum funderetur sanguis Stephani testis tui, ego astabam, et consentiebam, et custodiebam vestimenta interficientium illum.

verses.textEn: And he said to me, ‘Go forth. For I am sending you to far away nations.’ ”
verses.textLa: Et dixit ad me: Vade quoniam ego in nationes longe mittam te.

verses.textEn: Now they were listening to him, until this word, and then they lifted up their voice, saying: “Take this kind away from the earth! For it is not fitting for him to live!”
verses.textLa: Audiebant autem eum usque ad hoc verbum, et levaverunt vocem suam dicentes: Tolle de terra huiusmodi: non enim fas est eum vivere.

verses.textEn: And while they were shouting, and tossing aside their garments, and casting dust into the air,
verses.textLa: Vociferantibus autem eis, et proiicientibus vestimenta sua, et pulverem iactantibus in aerem,

verses.textEn: the tribune ordered him to be brought into the fortress, and to be scourged and tortured, in order to discover the reason that they were crying out in this way against him.
verses.textLa: iussit Tribunus induci eum in castra, et flagellis cædi, et torqueri eum, ut sciret propter quam causam sic acclamarent ei.

verses.textEn: And when they had tied him with straps, Paul said to the centurion who was standing near him, “Is it lawful for you to scourge a man who is a Roman and has not been condemned?”
verses.textLa: Et cum astrinxissent eum loris, dicit astanti sibi Centurioni Paulus: Si hominem Romanum, et indemnatum licet vobis flagellare?

verses.textEn: Upon hearing this, the centurion went to the tribune and reported it to him, saying: “What do you intend to do? For this man is a Roman citizen.”
verses.textLa: Quo audito, Centurio accessit ad Tribunum, et nunciavit ei, dicens: Quid acturus es? Hic enim homo civis Romanus est.

verses.textEn: And the tribune, approaching, said to him: “Tell me. Are you a Roman?” So he said, “Yes.”
verses.textLa: Accedens autem Tribunus, dixit illi: Dic mihi si tu Romanus es? At ille dixit: Etiam.

verses.textEn: And the tribune responded, “I obtained this citizenship at great cost.” And Paul said, “But I was born to it.”
verses.textLa: Et respondit Tribunus: Ego multa summa civilitatem hanc consecutus sum. Et Paulus ait: Ego autem et natus sum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, those who were going to torture him, immediately withdrew from him. The tribune was similarly afraid, after he realized that he was a Roman citizen, for he had bound him.
verses.textLa: Protinus ergo discesserunt ab illo, qui eum torturi erant. Tribunus quoque timuit postquam rescivit, quia civis Romanus esset, et quia alligasset eum.

verses.textEn: But on the next day, wanting to discover more diligently what the reason was that he was accused by the Jews, he released him, and he ordered the priests to convene, with the entire council. And, producing Paul, he stationed him among them.
verses.textLa: Postera autem die volens scire diligentius qua ex causa accusaretur a Iudæis, solvit eum, et iussit sacerdotes convenire, et omne concilium, et producens Paulum, statuit inter illos.

verses.textEn: Then Paul, gazing intently at the council, said, “Noble brothers, I have spoken with all good conscience before God, even to this present day.”
verses.textLa: Intendens autem in concilium Paulus ait: Viri fratres, ego omni conscientia bona conversatus sum ante Deum usque in hodiernum diem.

verses.textEn: And the high priest, Ananias, instructed those who were standing nearby to strike him on the mouth.
verses.textLa: Princeps autem sacerdotum Ananias præcepit astantibus sibi percutere os eius.

verses.textEn: Then Paul said to him: “God shall strike you, you whitewashed wall! For would you sit and judge me according to the law, when, contrary to the law, you order me to be struck?”
verses.textLa: Tunc Paulus dixit ad eum: Percutiet te Deus, paries dealbate. Et tu sedens iudicas me secundum legem, et contra legem iubes me percuti?

verses.textEn: And those who were standing nearby said, “Are you speaking evil about the high priest of God?”
verses.textLa: Et qui astabant dixerunt: Summum sacerdotem Dei maledicis.

verses.textEn: And Paul said: “I did not know, brothers, that he is the high priest. For it is written: ‘You shall not speak evil of the leader of your people.’ ”
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Paulus: Nesciebam fratres quia princeps est sacerdotum. Scriptum est enim: Principem populi tui non maledices.

verses.textEn: Now Paul, knowing that one group were Sadducees and the other were Pharisees, exclaimed in the council: “Noble brothers, I am a Pharisee, the son of Pharisees! It is over the hope and resurrection of the dead that I am being judged.”
verses.textLa: Sciens autem Paulus quia una pars esset Sadducæorum, et altera Pharisæorum, exclamavit in concilio: Viri fratres, ego Pharisæus sum, filius Pharisæorum, de spe et resurrectione mortuorum ego iudicor.

verses.textEn: And when he had said this, a dissension occurred between the Pharisees and the Sadducees. And the multitude was divided.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc dixisset, facta est dissensio inter Pharisæos, et Sadducæos, et soluta est multitudo.

verses.textEn: For the Sadducees claim that there is no resurrection, and neither angels, nor spirits. But the Pharisees confess both of these.
verses.textLa: Sadducæi enim dicunt, non esse resurrectionem, neque Angelum, neque spiritum: Pharisæi autem utraque confitentur.

verses.textEn: Then there occurred a great clamor. And some of the Pharisees, rising up, were fighting, saying: “We find nothing evil in this man. What if a spirit has spoken to him, or an angel?”
verses.textLa: Factus est autem clamor magnus. Et surgentes quidam Pharisæorum, pugnabant, dicentes: Nihil mali invenimus in homine isto: quid si spiritus locutus est ei, aut angelus?

verses.textEn: And since a great dissension had been made, the tribune, fearing that Paul might be torn apart by them, ordered the soldiers to descend and to seize him from their midst, and to bring him into the fortress.
verses.textLa: Et cum magna dissensio facta esset, timens Tribunus ne discerperetur Paulus ab ipsis, iussit milities descendere, et rapere eum de medio eorum, ac deducere eum in castra.

verses.textEn: Then, on the following night, the Lord stood near him and said: “Be constant. For just as you have testified about me in Jerusalem, so also it is necessary for you to testify at Rome.”
verses.textLa: Sequenti autem nocte assistens ei Dominus, ait: Constans esto: sicut enim testificatus es de me in Ierusalem, sic te oportet et Romæ testificari.

verses.textEn: And when daylight arrived, some of the Jews gathered together and bound themselves with an oath, saying that they would neither eat nor drink until they had killed Paul.
verses.textLa: Facta autem die collegerunt se quidam ex Iudæis, et devoverunt se dicentes, neque manducaturos, neque bibaturos donec occiderent Paulum.

verses.textEn: Now there were more than forty men who had taken this oath together.
verses.textLa: Erant autem plus quam quadraginta viri, qui hanc coniurationem fecerant:

verses.textEn: And they approached the leaders of the priests, and the elders, and they said: “We have sworn ourselves by an oath, so that we will taste nothing, until we have killed Paul.
verses.textLa: qui accesserunt ad principes sacerdotum, et seniores, et dixerunt: Devotione devovimus nos nihil gustaturos, donec occidamus Paulum.

verses.textEn: Therefore, with the council, you should now give notice to the tribune, so that he may bring him to you, as if you intended to determine something else about him. But before he approaches, we have made preparations to put him to death.”
verses.textLa: Nunc ergo vos notum facite Tribuno cum concilio, ut producat illum ad vos, tamquam aliquid certius cognituri de eo. Nos vero prius quam appropiet, parati sumus interficere illum.

verses.textEn: But when Paul’s sister’s son had heard of this, about their treachery, he went and entered into the fortress, and he reported it to Paul.
verses.textLa: Quod cum audisset filius sororis Pauli insidias, venit, et intravit in castra, nunciavitque Paulo.

verses.textEn: And Paul, calling to him one of the centurions, said: “Lead this young man to the tribune. For he has something to tell him.”
verses.textLa: Vocans autem Paulus ad se unum ex Centurionibus, ait: Adolescentem hunc perduc ad Tribunum, habet enim aliquid indicare illi.

verses.textEn: And indeed, he took him and led him to the tribune, and he said, “Paul, the prisoner, asked me to lead this young man to you, since he has something to say to you.”
verses.textLa: Et ille quidem assumens eum duxit ad Tribunum, et ait: Vinctus Paulus rogavit me hunc adolescentem perducere ad te, habentem aliquid loqui tibi.

verses.textEn: Then the tribune, taking him by the hand, withdrew with him by themselves, and he asked him: “What is it that you have to tell me?”
verses.textLa: Apprehendens autem Tribunus manum illius, secessit cum eo seorsum, et interrogavit illum: Quid est, quod habes indicare mihi?

verses.textEn: Then he said: “The Jews have met to ask you to bring Paul tomorrow to the council, as if they intended to question him about something else.
verses.textLa: Ille autem dixit: Iudæis convenit rogare te, ut crastina die producas Paulum in concilium, quasi aliquid certius inquisituri sint de illo:

verses.textEn: But truly, you should not believe them, for they would ambush him with more than forty men from among them, who have bound themselves by an oath neither to eat, nor to drink, until they have put him to death. And they are now prepared, hoping for an affirmation from you.”
verses.textLa: tu vero ne credideris illis, insidiantur enim ei ex eis viri amplius quam quadraginta, qui se devoverunt non manducare, neque bibere donec interficiant eum: et nunc parati sunt, exspectantes promissum tuum.

verses.textEn: And then the tribune dismissed the young man, instructing him not to tell anyone that he had made known these things to him.
verses.textLa: Tribunus igitur dimisit adolescentem, præcipiens ne cui loqueretur quoniam hæc nota sibi fecisset.

verses.textEn: Then, having called two centurions, he said to them: “Prepare two hundred soldiers, so that they may go as far as Caesarea, and seventy horsemen, and two hundred spearmen, for the third hour of the night.
