verses.textLa: Et vocatis duobus Centurionibus, dixit illis: Parate milites ducentos ut eant usque Cæsaream, et equites septuaginta, et lancearios ducentos a tertia hora noctis:
verses.notes: Each centurion was in charge of 100 soldiers.

verses.textEn: And prepare beasts of burden to carry Paul, so that they may lead him safely to Felix, the governor.”
verses.textLa: et iumenta præparate ut imponentes Paulum, salvum perducerent ad Felicem præsidem.

verses.textEn: For he was afraid, lest perhaps the Jews might seize him and kill him, and that afterwards he would be falsely accused, as if he had accepted a bribe. And so he wrote a letter containing the following:
verses.textLa: Timuit enim ne forte raperent eum Iudæi, et occiderent, et ipse postea calumniam sustineret, tamquam accepturus pecuniam,

verses.textEn: “Claudius Lysias, to the most excellent governor, Felix: greetings.
verses.textLa: scribens epistolam continentem hæc: CLAUDIUS Lysias optimo Præsidi, Felici salutem.

verses.textEn: This man, having been apprehended by the Jews and being about to be put to death by them, I rescued, overwhelming them with soldiers, since I realized that he is a Roman.
verses.textLa: Virum hunc comprehensum a Iudæis, et incipientem interfici ab eis, superveniens cum exercitu eripui, cognito quia Romanus est:
verses.notes: Here Scripture tells us that the tribune, Claudius, lied to the governor, Felix, making himself look good by saying that he know right away that Paul was a Roman, when such was not the case.

verses.textEn: And wanting to know the reason that they objected to him, I brought him into their council.
verses.textLa: Volensque scire causam, quam obiiciebant illi, deduxi eum in concilium eorum.

verses.textEn: And I discovered him to be accused about questions of their law. Yet truly, nothing deserving of death or imprisonment was within the accusation.
verses.textLa: Quem inveni accusari de quæstionibus legis ipsorum, nihil vero dignum morte aut vinculis habentem criminis.

verses.textEn: And when I had been given news of ambushes, which they had prepared against him, I sent him to you, notifying his accusers also, so that they may plead their accusations before you. Farewell.”
verses.textLa: Et cum mihi perlatum esset de insidiis, quas paraverant illi, misi eum ad te: denuncians et accusatoribus ut dicant apud te, Vale.

verses.textEn: Therefore the soldiers, taking Paul according to their orders, brought him by night to Antipatris.
verses.textLa: Milites ergo secundum præceptum sibi, assumentes Paulum, duxerunt per noctem in Antipatridem.

verses.textEn: And the next day, sending the horsemen to go with him, they returned to the fortress.
verses.textLa: Et postera die dimissis equitibus ut cum eo irent, reversi sunt ad castra.

verses.textEn: And when they had arrived at Caesarea and had delivered the letter to the governor, they also presented Paul before him.
verses.textLa: Qui cum venissent Cæsaream, et tradidissent epistolam præsidi, statuerunt ante illum et Paulum.

verses.textEn: And when he had read it and had asked which province he was from, realizing that he was from Cilicia, he said:
verses.textLa: Cum legisset autem, et interrogasset de qua provincia esset: et cognoscens quia de Cilicia,

verses.textEn: “I will hear you, when your accusers have arrived.” And he ordered him to be kept in the praetorium of Herod.
verses.textLa: Audiam te, inquit, cum accusatores tui venerint. Iussitque in prætorio Herodis custodiri eum.

verses.textEn: Then, after five days, the high priest Ananias came down with some of the elders and a certain Tertullus, a speaker. And they went to the governor against Paul.
verses.textLa: Post quinque autem dies descendit princeps sacerdotum, Ananias, cum senioribus quibusdam, et Tertullo quodam oratore, qui adierunt præsidem adversus Paulum.

verses.textEn: And having summoned Paul, Tertullus began to accuse him, saying: “Most excellent Felix, since we have much peace through you, and many things may be corrected by your providence,
verses.textLa: Et citato Paulo cœpit accusare Tertullus, dicens: Cum in multa pace agamus per te, et multa corrigantur per tuam providentiam;

verses.textEn: we acknowledge this, always and everywhere, with acts of thanksgiving for everything.
verses.textLa: semper et ubique suscipimus, optime Felix, cum omni gratiarum actione.

verses.textEn: But lest I speak at too great a length, I beg you, by your clemency, to listen to us briefly.
verses.textLa: Ne diutius autem te protraham, oro, breviter audias nos pro tua clementia.

verses.textEn: We have found this man to be pestilent, to be inciting seditions among all the Jews in the entire world, and to be the author of the sedition of the sect of the Nazarenes.
verses.textLa: Invenimus hunc hominem pestiferum, et concitantem seditiones omnibus Iudæis in universo orbe, et auctorem seditionis sectæ Nazarenorum:

verses.textEn: And he has even been attempting to violate the temple. And having apprehended him, we wanted him to be judged according to our law.
verses.textLa: qui etiam templum violare conatus est, quem et apprehensum voluimus secundum legem nostram iudicare.

verses.textEn: But Lysias, the tribune, overwhelming us with great violence, snatched him away from our hands,
verses.textLa: Superveniens autem Tribunus Lysias, cum vi magna eripuit eum de manibus nostris,

verses.textEn: ordering his accusers to come to you. From them, you yourself will be able, by judging about all these things, to understand the reason that we accuse him.”
verses.textLa: iubens accusatores eius ad te venire: a quo poteris ipse iudicans, de omnibus istis cognoscere, de quibus nos accusamus eum.

verses.textEn: And then the Jews interjected, saying that these things were so.
verses.textLa: Adiecerunt autem et Iudæi, dicentes hæc ita se habere.

verses.textEn: Then, since the governor had motioned for him to speak, Paul responded: “Knowing that you have been the judge over this nation for many years, I will give an explanation of myself with an honest soul.
verses.textLa: Respondit autem Paulus, (annuente sibi præside dicere): Ex multis annis te esse iudicem genti huic sciens, bono animo pro me satisfaciam.

verses.textEn: For, as you may realize, it has only been twelve days since I went up to worship in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Potes enim cognoscere quia non plus sunt mihi dies quam duodecim, ex quo ascendi adorare in Ierusalem:

verses.textEn: And they did not find me in the temple arguing with anyone, nor causing a rally of the people: neither in the synagogues, nor in the city.
verses.textLa: et neque in templo invenerunt me cum aliquo disputantem, aut concursum facientem turbæ, neque in synagogis, neque in civitate:

verses.textEn: And they are not able to prove to you the things about which they now accuse me.
verses.textLa: neque probare possunt tibi de quibus nunc me accusant.

verses.textEn: But I confess this to you, that according to that sect, which they call a heresy, so do I serve my God and Father, believing all that is written in the Law and the Prophets,
verses.textLa: Confiteor autem hoc tibi, quod secundum sectam, quam dicunt hæresim, sic deservio Patri, et Deo meo, credens omnibus, quæ in Lege, et Prophetis scripta sunt:

verses.textEn: having a hope in God, which these others themselves also expect, that there will be a future resurrection of the just and the unjust.
verses.textLa: spem habens in Deum, quam et hi ipsi expectant, resurrectionem futuram iustorum, et iniquorum.

verses.textEn: And in this, I myself always strive to have a conscience that is lacking in any offense toward God and toward men.
verses.textLa: In hoc et ipse studeo sine offendiculo conscientiam habere ad Deum, et ad homines semper.

verses.textEn: Then, after many years, I went to my nation, bringing alms and offerings and vows,
verses.textLa: Post annos autem plures eleemosynas facturus in gentem meam, veni, et oblationes, et vota,

verses.textEn: through which I obtained purification in the temple: neither with a crowd, nor with a commotion.
verses.textLa: in quibus invenerunt me purificatum in templo: non cum turba, neque cum tumultu.

verses.textEn: But certain Jews out of Asia are the ones who should have appeared before you to accuse me, if they have anything against me.
verses.textLa: Quidam autem ex Asia Iudæi, quos oportebat apud te præsto esse, et accusare, si quid haberent adversum me:

verses.textEn: Or let these ones here say if they have found in me any iniquity, while standing before the council.
verses.textLa: aut hi ipsi dicant si quid invenerunt in me iniquitatis cum stem in concilio,

verses.textEn: For while standing among them, I spoke out solely about this one matter: about the resurrection of the dead. It is about this that I am being judged today by you.”
verses.textLa: nisi de una hac solummodo voce, qua clamavi inter eos stans: Quoniam de resurrectione mortuorum ego iudicor hodie a vobis.

verses.textEn: Then Felix, after having ascertained much knowledge about this Way, kept them waiting, by saying, “When Lysias the tribune has arrived, I will give you a hearing.”
verses.textLa: Distulit autem illos Felix, certissime sciens de via hac, dicens: Cum Tribunus Lysias descenderit, audiam vos.

verses.textEn: And he ordered a centurion to guard him, and to take rest, and not to prohibit any of his own from ministering to him.
verses.textLa: Iussitque Centurioni custodire eum, et habere requiem, nec quemquam de suis prohibere ministrare ei.
verses.notes: In other words, the guard did not need to guard him 24/7, but could take rest breaks for himself. This guard was merely to keep tabs on Paul, not to restrict his activities.

verses.textEn: Then, after some days, Felix, arriving with his wife Drusilla who was a Jew, called for Paul and listened to him about the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
verses.textLa: Post aliquot autem dies veniens Felix cum Drusilla uxore sua, quæ erat Iudæa, vocavit Paulum, et audivit ab eo fidem, quæ est in Christum Iesum.

verses.textEn: And after he discoursed about justice and chastity, and about the future judgment, Felix was trembling, and he responded: “For now, go, but remain under guard. Then, at an opportune time, I will summon you.”
verses.textLa: Disputante autem illo de iustitia, et castitate, et de iudicio futuro, tremefactus Felix respondit: Quod nunc attinet, vade: tempore autem opportuno accersam te:

verses.textEn: He was also hoping that money might be given to him by Paul, and because of this, he frequently summoned him and spoke with him.
verses.textLa: simul et sperans, quod pecunia ei daretur a Paulo, propter quod et frequenter accersens eum, loquebatur cum eo.

verses.textEn: Then, when two years had passed, Felix was succeeded by Portius Festus. And since Felix wanted to show particular favor to the Jews, he left Paul behind as a prisoner.
verses.textLa: Biennio autem expleto, accepit successorem Felix Portium Festum. Volens autem gratiam præstare Iudæis Felix, reliquit Paulum vinctum.

verses.textEn: And so, when Festus had arrived in the province, after three days, he ascended to Jerusalem from Caesarea.
verses.textLa: Festus ergo cum venisset in provinciam, post triduum ascendit Ierosolymam a Cæsarea.

verses.textEn: And the leaders of the priests, and those first among the Jews, went to him against Paul. And they were petitioning him,
verses.textLa: Adieruntque eum principes sacerdotum, et primi Iudæorum adversus Paulum: et rogabant eum,

verses.textEn: asking for favor against him, so that he would order him to be led to Jerusalem, where they were maintaining an ambush in order to kill him along the way.
verses.textLa: postulantes gratiam adversus eum, ut iuberet perduci eum in Ierusalem, insidias tendentes ut interficerent eum in via.

verses.textEn: But Festus responded that Paul was to be kept in Caesarea, and that he himself would soon go there.
verses.textLa: Festus autem respondit servari Paulum in Cæsarea: se autem maturius profecturum.

verses.textEn: “Therefore,” he said, “let those among you who are able, descend at the same time, and if there is any guilt in the man, they may accuse him.”
verses.textLa: Qui ergo in vobis (ait) potentes sunt, descendentes simul, si quod est in viro crimen, accusent eum.

verses.textEn: Then, having stayed among them no more than eight or ten days, he descended to Caesarea. And on the next day, he sat in the judgment seat, and he ordered Paul to be led in.
verses.textLa: Demoratus autem inter eos dies non amplius quam octo, aut decem, descendit Cæsaream, et altera die sedit pro tribunali, et iussit Paulum adduci.

verses.textEn: And when he had been brought, the Jews who had come down from Jerusalem stood around him, throwing out many serious accusations, none of which they were able to prove.
verses.textLa: Qui cum perductus esset, circumsteterunt eum, qui ab Ierosolyma descenderant Iudæi, multas, et graves causas obiicientes, quas non poterant probare.

verses.textEn: Paul offered this defense: “Neither against the law of the Jews, nor against the temple, nor against Caesar, have I offended in any matter.”
verses.textLa: Paulo rationem reddente: Quoniam neque in legem Iudæorum, neque in templum, neque in Cæsarem quidquam peccavi.

verses.textEn: But Festus, wanting to show greater favor to the Jews, responded to Paul by saying: “Are you willing to ascend to Jerusalem and to be judged there about these things before me?”
verses.textLa: Festus autem volens gratiam præstare Iudæis, respondens Paulo, dixit: Vis Ierosolymam ascendere, et ibi de his iudicari apud me?
verses.notes: The Romans tended to favor the Jews. This was partly because Claudius, a previous emperor, issued an edict giving the Jewish faith a protected status in the empire. It may also have been because the wives of many powerful Roman leaders either converted to Judaism or tended to show favor to the Jews.

verses.textEn: But Paul said: “I stand in Caesar’s tribunal, which is where I ought to be judged. I have done no harm to the Jews, as you well know.
verses.textLa: Dixit autem Paulus: Ad tribunal Cæsaris sto, ibi me oportet iudicari: Iudæis non nocui, sicut tu melius nosti.

verses.textEn: For if I have harmed them, or if I have done anything deserving of death, I do not object to dying. But if there is nothing to these things about which they accuse me, no one is able to deliver me to them. I appeal to Caesar.”
verses.textLa: Si enim nocui, aut dignum morte aliquid feci, non recuso mori: si vero nihil est eorum, quæ hi accusant me, nemo potest me illis donare. Cæsarem appello.

verses.textEn: Then Festus, having spoken with the council, responded: “You have appealed to Caesar, to Caesar you shall go.”
verses.textLa: Tunc Festus cum concilio locutus, respondit: Cæsarem appellasti, ad Cæsarem ibis.

verses.textEn: And when some days had passed, king Agrippa and Bernice descended to Caesarea, to greet Festus.
verses.textLa: Et cum dies aliquot transacti essent: Agrippa rex, et Bernice descenderunt Cæsaream ad salutandum Festum.

verses.textEn: And since they remained there for many days, Festus spoke to the king about Paul, saying: “A certain man was left behind as a prisoner by Felix.
verses.textLa: Et cum dies plures ibi demorarentur, Festus regi indicavit de Paulo, dicens: Vir quidam est derelictus a Felice vinctus,

verses.textEn: When I was at Jerusalem, the leaders of the priests and the elders of the Jews came to me about him, asking for condemnation against him.
verses.textLa: de quo cum essem Ierosolymis, adierunt me principes sacerdotum, et seniores Iudæorum, postulantes adversus illum damnationem.

verses.textEn: I answered them that it is not the custom of the Romans to condemn any man, before he who is being accused has been confronted by his accusers and has received the opportunity to defend himself, so as to clear himself of the charges.
verses.textLa: Ad quos respondi: Quia non est Romanis consuetudo damnare aliquem hominem prius quam is, qui accusatur, præsentes habeat accusatores, locumque defendendi accipiat ad abluenda crimina.

verses.textEn: Therefore, when they had arrived here, without any delay, on the following day, sitting in the judgment seat, I ordered the man to be brought.
verses.textLa: Cum ergo huc convenissent sine ulla dilatione, sequenti die sedens pro tribunali, iussi adduci virum.

verses.textEn: But when the accusers had stood up, they did not present any accusation about him from which I would suspect evil.
verses.textLa: De quo, cum stetissent accusatores, nullam causam deferebant, de quibus ego suspicabar malum:

verses.textEn: Instead, they brought against him certain disputes about their own superstition and about a certain Jesus, who had died, but whom Paul asserted to be alive.
verses.textLa: Quæstiones vero quasdam de sua superstitione habebant adversus eum, et de quodam Iesu defuncto, quem affirmabat Paulus vivere.

verses.textEn: Therefore, being in doubt about this kind of question, I asked him if he was willing go to Jerusalem and to be judged there about these things.
verses.textLa: Hæsitans autem ego de huiusmodi quæstione, dicebam si vellet ire Ierosolymam, et ibi iudicari de istis.

verses.textEn: But since Paul was appealing to be kept for a decision before Augustus, I ordered him to be kept, until I might send him to Caesar.”
verses.textLa: Paulo autem appellante ut servaretur ad Augusti cognitionem, iussi servari eum, donec mittam eum ad Cæsarem.

verses.textEn: Then Agrippa said to Festus: “I myself also want to hear the man.” “Tomorrow,” he said, “you shall hear him.”
verses.textLa: Agrippa autem dixit ad Festum: Volebam et ipse hominem audire. Cras, inquit, audies eum.

verses.textEn: And on the next day, when Agrippa and Bernice had arrived with great ostentation and had entered into the auditorium with the tribunes and the principal men of the city, Paul was brought in, at the order of Festus.
verses.textLa: Altera autem die cum venisset Agrippa, et Bernice cum multa ambitione, et introissent in auditorium cum Tribunis, et viris principalibus civitatis, iubente Festo, adductus est Paulus.

verses.textEn: And Festus said: “King Agrippa, and all who are present together with us, you see this man, about whom all the multitude of the Jews disturbed me at Jerusalem, petitioning and clamoring that he should not be allowed to live any longer.
verses.textLa: Et dicit Festus: Agrippa rex, et omnes, qui simul adestis nobiscum viri, videtis hunc, de quo omnis multitudo Iudæorum interpellavit me Ierosolymis, petentes et acclamantes non oportere eum vivere amplius.

verses.textEn: Truly, I have discovered nothing brought forth against him that is worthy of death. But since he himself has appealed to Augustus, it was my judgment to send him.
verses.textLa: Ego vere comperi nihil dignum morte eum admisisse. Ipso autem hoc appellante ad Augustum, iudicavi mittere.
verses.notes: The emperor referred to as Augustus is actually Nero; it was the custom for Roman emperors to name themselves according to various prior Caesars. Thus Nero called himself Nero Claudius Caesar Augustus Germanicus, after the emperors Augustus, and Claudius, and Julius Caesar, and the general Germanicus.

verses.textEn: But I have not determined what to write to the emperor about him. Because of this, I have brought him before you all, and especially before you, O king Agrippa, so that, once an inquiry has occurred, I may have something to write.
verses.textLa: De quo quid certum scribam domino, non habeo. Propter quod produxi eum ad vos, et maxime ad te rex Agrippa, ut interrogatione facta habeam quid scribam.

verses.textEn: For it seems to me unreasonable to send a prisoner and not to indicate the accusations set against him.”
verses.textLa: Sine ratione enim mihi videtur mittere vinctum, et causas eius non significare.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, Agrippa said to Paul, “It is permitted for you to speak for yourself.” Then Paul, extending his hand, began to offer his defense.
verses.textLa: Agrippa vero ad Paulum ait: Permittitur tibi loqui pro temetipso. Tunc Paulus extenta manu cœpit rationem reddere.

verses.textEn: “I consider myself blessed, O king Agrippa, that I am to give my defense today before you, about everything of which I am accused by the Jews,
verses.textLa: De omnibus, quibus accusor a Iudæis, rex Agrippa, æstimo me beatum, apud te cum sim defensurus me hodie,

verses.textEn: especially since you know everything that pertains to the Jews, both customs and questions. Because of this, I beg you to listen to me patiently.
verses.textLa: maxime te sciente omnia, et quæ apud Iudæos sunt consuetudines, et quæstiones: propter quod obsecro patienter me audias.

verses.textEn: And certainly, all the Jews know about my life from my youth, which had its beginning among my own people in Jerusalem.
verses.textLa: Et quidem vitam meam a iuventute, quæ ab initio fuit in gente mea in Ierosolymis, noverunt omnes Iudæi:

verses.textEn: They knew me well from the beginning, (if they would be willing to offer testimony) for I lived according to the most determined sect of our religion: as a Pharisee.
verses.textLa: præscientes me ab initio (si velint testimonium perhibere) quoniam secundum certissimam sectam nostræ religionis vixi Pharisæus.

verses.textEn: And now, it is in the hope of the Promise which was made by God to our fathers that I stand subject to judgment.
verses.textLa: Et nunc in spe, quæ ad patres nostros repromissionis facta est a Deo, sto iudicio subiectus:

verses.textEn: It is the Promise that our twelve tribes, worshiping night and day, hope to see. About this hope, O king, I am accused by the Jews.
verses.textLa: in quam duodecim tribus nostræ nocte ac die deservientes, sperant devenire. De qua spe accusor a Iudæis, rex.

verses.textEn: Why should it be judged so unbelievable with you all that God might raise the dead?
verses.textLa: Quid incredibile iudicatur apud vos, si Deus mortuos suscitat?

verses.textEn: And certainly, I myself formerly considered that I ought to act in many ways which are contrary to the name of Jesus the Nazarene.
verses.textLa: Et ego quidem existimaveram, me adversus nomen Iesu Nazareni debere multa contraria agere.

verses.textEn: This is also how I acted at Jerusalem. And so, I enclosed many holy persons in prison, having received authority from the leaders of the priests. And when they were to be killed, I brought the sentence.
verses.textLa: Quod et feci Ierosolymis, et multos sanctorum ego in carceribus inclusi, a principibus sacerdotum potestate accepta: et cum occiderentur, detuli sententiam.

verses.textEn: And in every synagogue, frequently while punishing them, I compelled them to blaspheme. And being all the more maddened against them, I persecuted them, even to foreign cities.
verses.textLa: Et per omnes synagogas frequenter puniens eos, compellebam blasphemare: et amplius insaniens in eos, persequebar usque in exteras civitates.

verses.textEn: Thereafter, as I was going to Damascus, with authority and permission from the high priest,
verses.textLa: In quibus dum irem Damascum cum potestate, et permissu principum sacerdotum,

verses.textEn: at midday, O king, I and those who were also with me, saw along the way a light from heaven shining around me with a splendor greater than that of the sun.
verses.textLa: die media in via, vidi, rex, de cælo supra splendorem solis circumfulsisse me lumen, et eos, qui mecum simul erant.

verses.textEn: And when we had all fallen down to the ground, I heard a voice speaking to me in the Hebrew language: ‘Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me? It is hard for you to kick against the goad.’
verses.textLa: Omnesque nos cum decidissemus in terram, audivi vocem loquentem mihi Hebraica lingua: Saule, Saule, quid me persequeris? Durum est tibi contra stimulum calcitrare.

verses.textEn: Then I said, ‘Who are you, Lord?’ And the Lord said, ‘I am Jesus, whom you are persecuting.
verses.textLa: Ego autem dixi: Quis es Domine? Dominus autem dixit: Ego sum Iesus, quem tu persequeris.

verses.textEn: But rise up and stand on your feet. For I appeared to you for this reason: so that I may establish you as a minister and a witness concerning the things that you have seen, and concerning the things that I will show to you:
verses.textLa: Sed exurge, et sta super pedes tuos: ad hoc enim apparui tibi, ut constituam te ministrum, et testem eorum, quæ vidisti, et eorum, quibus apparebo tibi,

verses.textEn: rescuing you from the people and the nations to which I am now sending you,
verses.textLa: eripiens te de populo, et gentibus, in quas nunc ego mitto te,

verses.textEn: in order to open their eyes, so that they may be converted from darkness to light, and from the power of Satan to God, so that they may receive the remission of sins and a place among the saints, through the faith that is in me.’
verses.textLa: aperire oculos eorum, ut convertantur a tenebris ad lucem, et de potestate Satanæ ad Deum, ut accipiant remissionem peccatorum, et sortem inter sanctos per fidem, quæ est in me.

verses.textEn: From then on, O king Agrippa, I was not unbelieving to the heavenly vision.
verses.textLa: Unde rex Agrippa, non fui incredulus cælesti visioni:

verses.textEn: But I preached, first to those who are at Damascus and at Jerusalem, and then to the entire region of Judea, and to the Gentiles, so that they would repent and convert to God, doing the works that are worthy of repentance.
verses.textLa: sed his, qui sunt Damasci primum, et Ierosolymis, et in omnem regionem Iudææ, et Gentibus annunciabam, ut pœnitentiam agerent, et converterentur ad Deum, digna pœnitentiæ opera facientes.

verses.textEn: It was for this reason that the Jews, having apprehended me when I was in the temple, attempted to kill me.
verses.textLa: Hac ex causa me Iudæi, cum essem in templo, comprehensum tentabant interficere.

verses.textEn: But having been aided by the help of God, even to this day, I stand witnessing to the small and the great, saying nothing beyond what the Prophets and Moses have said would be in the future:
verses.textLa: Auxilio autem adiutus Dei usque in hodiernum diem sto, testificans minori, atque maiori, nihil extra dicens quam ea, quæ Prophetæ locuti sunt futura esse, et Moyses,

verses.textEn: that the Christ would suffer, and that he would be the first from the resurrection of the dead, and that he would bring light to the people and to the nations.”
verses.textLa: si passibilis Christus, si primus ex resurrectione mortuorum, lumen annunciaturus est populo, et gentibus.

verses.textEn: While he was speaking these things and presenting his defense, Festus said with a loud voice: “Paul, you are insane! Too much studying has turned you to insanity.”
verses.textLa: Hæc loquente eo, et rationem reddente, Festus magna voce dixit: Insanis Paule: multæ te litteræ ad insaniam convertunt.

verses.textEn: And Paul said: “I am not insane, most excellent Festus, but rather I am speaking words of truth and sobriety.
verses.textLa: Et Paulus: Non insanio (inquit) optime Feste, sed veritatis, et sobrietatis verba loquor.

verses.textEn: For the king knows about these things. To him also, I am speaking with constancy. For I think that none of these things are unknown to him. And neither were these things done in a corner.
verses.textLa: Scit enim de his rex, ad quem et constanter loquor: latere enim eum nihil horum arbitror. Neque enim in angulo quidquam horum gestum est.

verses.textEn: Do you believe the Prophets, O king Agrippa? I know that you believe.”
verses.textLa: Credis rex Agrippa prophetis? Scio quia credis.

verses.textEn: Then Agrippa said to Paul, “To some extent, you persuade me to become a Christian.”
verses.textLa: Agrippa autem ad Paulum: In modico suades me Christianum fieri.

verses.textEn: And Paul said, “I hope to God that, both to a small extent and to a great extent, not only you, but also all those who hear me this day will become just as I also am, except for these chains.”
verses.textLa: Et Paulus: Opto apud Deum, et in modico, et in magno, non tantum te, sed etiam omnes, qui audiunt, hodie fieri tales, qualis et ego sum, exceptis vinculis his.

verses.textEn: And the king rose up, and the governor, and Bernice, and those who were sitting with them.
verses.textLa: Et exurrexit rex, et præses, et Bernice, et qui assidebant eis.

verses.textEn: And when they had withdrawn, they were speaking among themselves, saying, “This man has done nothing worthy of death, nor of imprisonment.”
verses.textLa: Et cum secessissent, loquebantur ad invicem, dicentes: Quia nihil morte, aut vinculis dignum quid fecit homo iste.

verses.textEn: Then Agrippa said to Festus, “This man could have been released, if he had not appealed to Caesar.”
verses.textLa: Agrippa autem Festo dixit: Dimitti poterat homo hic, si non appellasset Cæsarem.

verses.textEn: Then it was decided to send him by ship to Italy, and that Paul, with the others in custody, should be delivered to a centurion named Julius, of the cohort of Augusta.
verses.textLa: Ut autem iudicatum est navigare eum in Italiam, et tradi Paulum cum reliquis custodiis centurioni nomine Iulio cohortis Augustæ,

verses.textEn: After climbing aboard a ship from Adramyttium, we set sail and began to navigate along the ports of Asia, with Aristarchus, the Macedonian from Thessalonica, joining us.
verses.textLa: ascendentes navem Adrumetinam, incipientes navigare circa Asiæ loca, sustulimus, perseverante nobiscum Aristarcho Macedone Thessalonicensi.

verses.textEn: And on the following day, we arrived at Sidon. And Julius, treating Paul humanely, permitted him to go to his friends and to look after himself.
verses.textLa: Sequenti autem die devenimus Sidonem. Humane autem tractans Iulius Paulum, permisit ad amicos ire, et curam sui agere.

verses.textEn: And when we had set sail from there, we navigated below Cyprus, because the winds were contrary.
verses.textLa: Et inde cum sustulissemus, subnavigavimus Cyprum, propter ea quod essent venti contrarii.

verses.textEn: And navigating though the sea of Cilicia and Pamphylia, we arrived at Lystra, which is in Lycia.
verses.textLa: Et pelagus Ciliciæ, et Pamphyliæ navigantes, venimus Lystram, quæ est Lyciæ:

verses.textEn: And there the centurion found a ship from Alexandria sailing to Italy, and he transferred us to it.
verses.textLa: et ibi inveniens centurio navem Alexandrinam navigantem in Italiam, transposuit nos in eam.

verses.textEn: And when we had sailed slowly for many days and had barely arrived opposite Cnidus, for the wind was hindering us, we sailed to Crete, near Salmone.
verses.textLa: Et cum multis diebus tarde navigaremus, et vix devenissemus contra Gnidum, prohibente nos vento, adnavigavimus Cretæ iuxta Salmonem:

verses.textEn: And barely being able to sail past it, we arrived at a certain place, which is called Good Shelter, next to which was the city of Lasea.
verses.textLa: et vix iuxta navigantes, venimus in locum quendam, qui vocatur Boni Portus, cui iuxta erat civitas Thalassa.

verses.textEn: Then, after much time had passed, and since sailing would no longer be prudent because the Fast Day had now passed, Paul consoled them,
verses.textLa: Multo autem tempore peracto, et cum iam non esset tuta navigatio, eo quod et ieiunium iam præteriisset, consolabatur eos Paulus,

verses.textEn: and he said to them: “Men, I perceive that the voyage is now in danger of injury and much damage, not only to the cargo and the ship, but also to our own lives.”
verses.textLa: dicens eis: Viri, video quoniam cum iniuria, et multo damno non solum oneris, et navis, sed etiam animarum nostrarum incipit esse navigatio.
verses.notes: In those days, the Mediterranean was not considered safe to sail during the winter months, from after the Fast Day (Yom Kippur) to early February, because of an increase in the number and severity of storms.

verses.textEn: But the centurion put more trust in the captain and the navigator of the ship, than in the things being said by Paul.
verses.textLa: Centurio autem gubernatori et nauclero magis credebat, quam his, quæ a Paulo dicebantur.

verses.textEn: And since it was not a fitting port in which to winter, the majority opinion was to sail from there, so that somehow they might be able to arrive at Phoenicia, in order to winter there, at a port of Crete, which looks out toward the southwest and northwest.
verses.textLa: Et cum aptus portus non esset ad hiemandum, plurimi statuerunt consilium navigare inde, si quomodo possent, devenientes Phœnicen, hiemare, portum Cretæ respicientem ad Africum, et ad Corum.

verses.textEn: And since the south wind was blowing gently, they thought that they might reach their goal. And after they had set out from Asson, they weighed anchor at Crete.
verses.textLa: Aspirante autem Austro, æstimantes propositum se tenere, cum sustulissent de Asson, legebant Cretam.

verses.textEn: But not long afterward, a violent wind came against them, which is called the Northeast Wind.
verses.textLa: Non post multum autem misit se contra ipsam ventus Typhonicus, qui vocatur Euroaquilo.

verses.textEn: And once the ship had been caught in it and was not able to strive against the wind, giving over the ship to the winds, we were driven along.
verses.textLa: Cumque arrepta esset navis, et non posset conari in ventum, data nave flatibus, ferebamur.

verses.textEn: Then, being forced along a certain island, which is called the Tail, we were barely able to hold on to the ship’s lifeboat.
verses.textLa: In insulam autem quandam decurrentes, quæ vocatur Cauda, potuimus vix obtinere scapham.
verses.notes: The word ‘scapham’ does not refer to the ship ‘navem’ that they were sailing, but to the smaller boat, usually hauled behind the larger boat, used for going ashore.

verses.textEn: When this was taken up, they used it to assist in securing the ship. For they were afraid that they might run aground. And having lowered the sails, they were being driven along in this way.
verses.textLa: Qua sublata, adiutoriis utebantur, accingentes navem, timentes ne in Syrtim inciderent, summisso vase sic ferebantur.
verses.notes: They took the smaller boat used for going ashore into the larger boat and then they used it in strengthening the larger boat. They were afraid that they would hit a sandbar, partly because ships tend to ride low in the water during a storm (because they take on water), and because they had less control over its direction. They took down the sails, so that they would not be driven aground on the island.

verses.textEn: Then, since we were being tossed about strongly by the tempest, on the following day, they threw the heavy items overboard.
verses.textLa: Valida autem nobis tempestate iactatis, sequenti die iactum fecerunt:

verses.textEn: And on the third day, with their own hands, they threw the equipment of the ship overboard.
verses.textLa: et tertia die suis manibus armamenta navis proiecerunt.

verses.textEn: Then, when neither sun nor stars appeared for many days, and no end to the storm was imminent, all hope for our safety was now taken away.
verses.textLa: Neque autem sole, neque sideribus apparentibus per plures dies, et tempestate non exigua imminente, iam ablata erat spes omnis salutis nostræ.

verses.textEn: And after they had fasted for a long time, Paul, standing in their midst, said: “Certainly, men, you should have listened to me and not set out from Crete, so as to cause this injury and loss.
verses.textLa: Et cum multa ieiunatio fuisset, tunc stans Paulus in medio eorum, dixit: Oportebat quidem, o viri, audito me, non tollere a Creta, lucrique facere iniuriam hanc, et iacturam.

verses.textEn: And now, let me persuade you to be courageous in soul. For there shall be no loss of life among you, but only of the ship.
verses.textLa: Et nunc suadeo vobis bono animo esse. Amissio enim nullius animæ erit ex vobis, præterquam navis.

verses.textEn: For an Angel of God, who is assigned to me and whom I serve, stood beside me this night,
verses.textLa: Astitit enim mihi hac nocte Angelus Dei, cuius sum ego, et cui deservio,

verses.textEn: saying: ‘Do not be afraid, Paul! It is necessary for you to stand before Caesar. And behold, God has given to you all those who are sailing with you.’
verses.textLa: dicens: Ne timeas Paule, Cæsari te oportet assistere: et ecce donavit tibi Deus omnes, qui navigant tecum.

verses.textEn: Because of this, men, be courageous in soul. For I trust God that this will happen in the same way that it has been told to me.
verses.textLa: Propter quod bono animo estote viri: credo enim Deo, quia sic erit, quemadmodum dictum est mihi.

verses.textEn: But it is necessary for us to arrive at a certain island.”
verses.textLa: In insulam autem quandam oportet nos devenire.

verses.textEn: Then, after the fourteenth night arrived, as we were navigating in the sea of Adria, about the middle of the night, the sailors believed that they saw some portion of the land.
verses.textLa: Sed postea quam quartadecima nox supervenit, navigantibus nobis in Adria circa mediam noctem, suspicabantur nautæ apparere sibi aliquam regionem.

verses.textEn: And upon dropping a weight, they found a depth of twenty paces. And some distance from there, they found a depth of fifteen paces.
verses.textLa: Qui et summittentes bolidem, invenerunt passus viginti: et pusillum inde separati, invenerunt passus quindecim.

verses.textEn: Then, fearing that we might happen upon rough places, they cast four anchors out of the stern, and they were hoping for daylight to arrive soon.
verses.textLa: Timentes autem ne in aspera loca incideremus, de puppi mittentes anchoras quattuor, optabant diem fieri.

verses.textEn: Yet truly, the sailors were seeking a way to flee from the ship, for they had lowered a lifeboat into the sea, on the pretext that they were attempting to cast anchors from the bow of the ship.
verses.textLa: Nautis vero quærentibus fugere de navi, cum misissent scapham in mare, sub obtentu quasi inciperent a prora anchoras extendere,

verses.textEn: So Paul said to the centurion and to the soldiers, “Unless these men remain in the ship, you will not be able to be saved.”
verses.textLa: dixit Paulus Centurioni, et militibus: Nisi hi in navi manserint, vos salvi fieri non potestis.

verses.textEn: Then the soldiers cut the ropes to the lifeboat, and they allowed it to fall.
verses.textLa: Tunc absciderunt milites funes scaphæ, et passi sunt eam excidere.

verses.textEn: And when it began to be light, Paul requested that they all take food, saying: “This is the fourteenth day that you have been waiting and continuing to fast, taking nothing.
verses.textLa: Et cum lux inciperet fieri, rogabat Paulus omnes sumere cibum, dicens: Quartadecima die hodie expectantes ieiuni permanetis, nihil accipientes.

verses.textEn: For this reason, I beg you to accept food for the sake of your health. For not a hair from the head of any of you shall perish.”
verses.textLa: Propter quod rogo vos accipere cibum pro salute vestra: quia nullius vestrum capillus de capite peribit.

verses.textEn: And when he had said these things, taking bread, he gave thanks to God in the sight of them all. And when he had broken it, he began to eat.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc dixisset, sumens panem, gratias egit Deo in conspectu omnium: et cum fregisset, cœpit manducare.

verses.textEn: Then they all became more peaceful in soul. And they also took food.
verses.textLa: Animæquiores autem facti omnes, et ipsi sumpserunt cibum.

verses.textEn: Truly, we were two hundred and seventy-six souls on the ship.
verses.textLa: Eramus vero universæ animæ in navi ducentæ septuaginta sex.

verses.textEn: And having been nourished with food, they lightened the ship, casting the wheat into the sea.
verses.textLa: Et satiati cibo alleviabant navem, iactantes triticum in mare.

verses.textEn: And when day had arrived, they did not recognize the landscape. Yet truly, they caught sight of a certain narrow inlet having a shore, into which they thought it might be possible to force the ship.
verses.textLa: Cum autem dies factus esset, terram non agnoscebant: sinum vero quendam considerabant habentem littus, in quem cogitabant, si possent, eiicere navem.

verses.textEn: And when they had taken up the anchors, they committed themselves to the sea, at the same time loosing the restraints of the rudders. And so, raising the mainsail to the gusting wind, they pressed on toward the shore.
verses.textLa: Et cum anchoras sustulissent, committebant se mari, simul laxantes iuncturas gubernaculorum: et levato artemone secundum auræ flatum tendebant ad littus.

verses.textEn: And when we happened upon a place open to two seas, they ran the ship aground. And indeed, the bow, being immobilized, remained fixed, but truly the stern was broken by the violence of the sea.
verses.textLa: Et cum incidissemus in locum dithalassum, impegerunt navem: et prora quidem fixa manebat immobilis, puppis vero solvebatur a vi maris.

verses.textEn: Then the soldiers were in agreement that they should kill the prisoners, lest anyone, after escaping by swimming, might flee.
verses.textLa: Militum autem consilium fuit ut custodias occiderent: ne quis cum enatasset, effugeret.

verses.textEn: But the centurion, wanting to save Paul, prohibited it from being done. And he ordered those who were able to swim to jump in first, and to escape, and to get to the land.
verses.textLa: Centurio autem volens servare Paulum, prohibuit fieri: iussitque eos, qui possent natare, emittere se primos, et evadere, et ad terram exire:

verses.textEn: And as for the others, some they carried on boards, and others on those things that belonged to the ship. And so it happened that every soul escaped to the land.
verses.textLa: et ceteros alios in tabulis ferebant: quosdam super ea, quæ de navi erant. Et sic factum est, ut omnes animæ evaderent ad terram.

verses.textEn: And after we had escaped, we then realized that the island was called Malta. Yet truly, the natives offered us no small amount of humane treatment.
verses.textLa: Et cum evasissemus, tunc cognovimus quia Melita insula vocabatur. Barbari vero præstabant non modicam humanitatem nobis.

verses.textEn: For they refreshed us all by kindling a fire, because rain was imminent and because of the cold.
verses.textLa: Accensa enim pyra, reficiebant nos omnes propter imbrem, qui imminebat, et frigus.

verses.textEn: But when Paul had gathered together a bundle of twigs, and had placed them on the fire, a viper, which had been drawn to the heat, fastened itself to his hand.
verses.textLa: Cum congregasset autem Paulus sarmentorum aliquantam multitudinem, et imposuisset super ignem, vipera a calore cum processisset, invasit manum eius.

verses.textEn: And truly, when the natives saw the beast hanging from his hand, they were saying to one another: “Certainly, this man must be a murderer, for though he escaped from the sea, vengeance will not permit him to live.”
verses.textLa: Ut vero viderunt Barbari pendentem bestiam de manu eius, ad invicem dicebant: Utique homicida est homo hic, qui cum evaserit de mari, ultio non sinit eum vivere.

verses.textEn: But shaking off the creature into the fire, he indeed suffered no ill effects.
verses.textLa: Et ille quidem excutiens bestiam in ignem, nihil mali passus est.

verses.textEn: But they were supposing that he would soon swell up, and then would suddenly fall down and die. But having waited a long time, and seeing no ill effects in him, they changed their minds and were saying that he was a god.
verses.textLa: At illi existimabant eum in tumorem convertendum, et subito casurum, et mori. Diu autem illis expectantibus, et videntibus nihil mali in eo fieri, convertentes se, dicebant eum esse deum.

verses.textEn: Now among these places were estates owned by the ruler of the island, named Publius. And he, taking us in, showed us kind hospitality for three days.
verses.textLa: In locis autem illis erant prædia principis insulæ, nomine Publii, qui nos suscipiens, triduo benigne exhibuit.

verses.textEn: Then it happened that the father of Publius lay ill with a fever and with dysentery. Paul entered to him, and when he had prayed and had laid his hands on him, he saved him.
verses.textLa: Contigit autem, patrem Publii febribus, et dysenteria vexatum iacere. Ad quem Paulus intravit: et cum orasset, et imposuisset ei manus, salvavit eum.

verses.textEn: When this had been done, all who had diseases on the island approached and were cured.
verses.textLa: Quo facto, omnes qui in insula habebant infirmitates, accedebant, et curabantur:

verses.textEn: And then they also presented us with many honors. And when we were ready to set sail, they gave us whatever we needed.
verses.textLa: qui etiam multis honoribus nos honoraverunt, et navigantibus imposuerunt quæ necessaria erant.

verses.textEn: And so, after three months, we sailed in a ship from Alexandria, whose name was ‘the Castors,’ and which had wintered at the island.
verses.textLa: Post menses autem tres navigavimus in navi Alexandrina, quæ in insula hiemaverat, cui erat insigne Castorum.
verses.notes: The name Castor refers to a prominent star (the stars were used by sailors for navigation), and also to a figure in Greek mythology, one of the Gemini twins. Since the name in Latin is in the genitive case, it implies that the ship was considered to belong to, or to be under the protection of, these Greek mythological gods.

verses.textEn: And when we had arrived at Syracuse, we were delayed there for three days.
verses.textLa: Et cum venissemus Syracusam, mansimus ibi triduo.

verses.textEn: From there, sailing close to the shore, we arrived at Rhegium. And after one day, with the south wind blowing, we arrived on the second day at Puteoli.
verses.textLa: Inde circumlegentes devenimus Rhegium: et post unum diem flante Austro, secunda die venimus Puteolos;

verses.textEn: There, after locating the brothers, we were asked to remain with them for seven days. And then we went on to Rome.
verses.textLa: ubi inventis fratribus rogati sumus manere apud eos dies septem: et sic venimus Romam.

verses.textEn: And there, when the brothers had heard of us, they went to meet us as far as the Forum of Appius and the Three Taverns. And when Paul had seen them, giving thanks to God, he took courage.
verses.textLa: Et inde cum audissent fratres, occurrerunt nobis usque ad Appii forum, ac tres Tabernas. Quos cum vidisset Paulus, gratias agens Deo, accepit fiduciam.

verses.textEn: And when we had arrived at Rome, Paul was given permission to stay by himself, with a soldier to guard him.
verses.textLa: Cum autem venissemus Romam, permissum est Paulo manere sibimet cum custodiente se milite.

verses.textEn: And after the third day, he called together the leaders of the Jews. And when they had convened, he said to them: “Noble brothers, I have done nothing against the people, nor against the customs of the fathers, yet I was delivered as a prisoner from Jerusalem into the hands of the Romans.
verses.textLa: Post tertium autem diem convocavit primos Iudæorum. Cumque convenissent, dicebat eis: Ego, viri fratres, nihil adversus plebem faciens, aut morem paternum, vinctus ab Ierosolymis traditus sum in manus Romanorum,

verses.textEn: And after they held a hearing about me, they would have released me, because there was no case for death against me.
verses.textLa: qui cum interrogationem de me habuissent, voluerunt me dimittere, eo quod nulla esset causa mortis in me.

verses.textEn: But with the Jews speaking against me, I was constrained to appeal to Caesar, though it was not as if I had any kind of accusation against my own nation.
verses.textLa: Contradicentibus autem Iudæis, coactus sum appellare Cæsarem, non quasi gentem meam habens aliquid accusare.

verses.textEn: And so, because of this, I requested to see you and to speak to you. For it is because of the hope of Israel that I am encircled with this chain.”
verses.textLa: Propter hanc igitur causam rogavi vos videre, et alloqui. Propter spem enim Israel catena hac circumdatus sum.

verses.textEn: But they said to him: “We have not received letters about you from Judea, nor have any of the other new arrivals among the brothers reported or spoken anything evil against you.
verses.textLa: At illi dixerunt ad eum: Nos neque litteras accepimus de te a Iudæa, neque adveniens aliquis fratrum nunciavit, aut locutus est quid de te malum.

verses.textEn: But we are asking to hear your opinions from you, for concerning this sect, we know that it is being spoken against everywhere.”
verses.textLa: Rogamus autem a te audire quæ sentis: nam de secta hac notum est nobis quia ubique ei contradicitur.

verses.textEn: And when they had appointed a day for him, very many persons went to him at his guest quarters. And he discoursed, testifying to the kingdom of God, and persuading them about Jesus, using the law of Moses and the Prophets, from morning until evening.
verses.textLa: Cum constituissent autem illi diem, venerunt ad eum in hospitium plurimi, quibus exponebat testificans regnum Dei, suadensque eis de Iesu ex Lege Moysi, et Prophetis a mane usque ad vesperam.

verses.textEn: And some believed the things that he was saying, yet others did not believe.
verses.textLa: Et quidam credebant his, quæ dicebantur: quidam vero non credebant.

verses.textEn: And when they could not agree among themselves, they departed, while Paul was speaking this one word: “How well did the Holy Spirit speak to our fathers through the prophet Isaiah,
verses.textLa: Cumque invicem non essent consentientes, discedebant dicente Paulo unum verbum: Quia bene Spiritus Sanctus locutus est per Isaiam prophetam ad patres nostros,

verses.textEn: saying: ‘Go to this people and say to them: Hearing, you shall hear and not understand, and seeing, you shall see and not perceive.
verses.textLa: dicens: Vade ad populum istum, et dic ad eos: Aure audietis, et non intelligetis: et videntes videbitis, et non perspicietis.

verses.textEn: For the heart of this people has grown dull, and they have listened with reluctant ears, and they have closed their eyes tightly, lest perhaps they might see with the eyes, and hear with the ears, and understand with the heart, and so be converted, and I would heal them.’
verses.textLa: Incrassatum est enim cor populi huius, et auribus graviter audierunt, et oculos suos compresserunt: ne forte videant oculis, et auribus audiant, et corde intelligant, et convertantur, et sanem eos.

verses.textEn: Therefore, let it be known to you, that this salvation of God has been sent to the Gentiles, and they shall listen to it.”
verses.textLa: Notum ergo sit vobis, quoniam Gentibus missum est hoc salutare Dei, et ipsi audient.

verses.textEn: And when he had said these things, the Jews went away from him, though they still had many questions among themselves.
verses.textLa: Et cum hæc dixisset, exierunt ab eo Iudæi, multam habentes inter se quæstionem.

verses.textEn: Then he remained for two whole years in his own rented lodgings. And he received all who went in to him,
verses.textLa: Mansit autem biennio toto in suo conducto: et suscipiebat omnes, qui ingrediebantur ad eum,

verses.textEn: preaching the kingdom of God and teaching the things which are from the Lord Jesus Christ, with all faithfulness, without prohibition.
verses.textLa: prædicans regnum Dei, et docens quæ sunt de Domino Iesu Christo cum omni fiducia, sine prohibitione.
